Without this word (I thank you) to a fool.
I see no reason why that dog (Called chance)
Should fawn upon this fellow more than me:
I am a man, and I have limbs, flesh, blood,
Bones, sinews, and a soul as well as he:
my parts are every way as good as his,
If I said better? why I did not lie,
Natheless his wealth (But nodding on my wants)
Must make me bow, and cry: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Dispatch, take heed your mistress see you not.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Nay gentle friend be merry, raise your looks
Out of your bosom, I protest (By heaven)
You are the man most welcome in the world.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I thank you sir, I know my cue I think.

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: Where will you have 'em burn sir?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Here good Fido:
What? she did not see thee?

sp.speaker: Fido.
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: That's well:
Strew, strew, good Fido, the freshest flowers, so.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What means this signior Deliro?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Cast in more frankincense, yet more, well said.
O Macilente, I have such a wife,
So passing fair, so passing fair unkind,
And of such worth and right to be unkind,
(Since no man can be worthy of her kindness.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What can there not?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: No, that is sure as death,
No man alive: I do not say is not,
But cannot possibly be worth her kindness.
Nay that is certain, let me do her right:
How said I? do her right? as though I could,
As though this dull gross tongue of mine could utter
The rare, the true, the pure, the infinite rights
That sit (As high as I can look) within her.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: This is such dotage as was never heard.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Well, this must needs be granted.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.l: Granted quoth you?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Nay Macilente; do not so discredit
the goodness of your judgement to deny it,
For I do speak the very least of her.
And I would crave and beg no more of heaven
For all my fortunes here, but to be able
To utter first in fit terms, what she is,
And then the true joys I conceive in her.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.l: Is't possible she should deserve so well
As you pretend?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Ay, and she knows so well
Her own deserts that (When I strive t'enjoy them)
She ways the things I do, with what she merits:
And (Seeing my worth outweighed so in her graces)
She is so solemn, so precise, so froward,
That no observance I can do to her,
Can make her kind to me: if she find fault,
I mend that fault, and then she says I faulted
That I did mend it. Now good friend advise me
How I may temper this strange spleen in her.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: You are too amorous, too obsequious,
And make her, too assured she may command you.
When women doubt most of their husband's loves,
They are most loving. Husband's must take heed
They give no gluts of kindness to their wives,
But use them like their horses, whom they feed
Not with a manger-ful of meat together,
But half a peck at once, and keep them so
Still with an appetite to that they give them.
He that desires to have a loving wife,
Must bridle all the show of that desire:
Be kind, not amorous, nor bewraying kindness,
As if love wrought it, but considerate duty:
"Offer no love-rites, but let wives still seek them,
" for when they come unsought, they seldom like them.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Believe me Macilente, this is gospel.
O that a man were his own man so much,
To rule himself thus; I will strive i' faith
to be more strange and careless: yet I hope
I have now taken such a perfect course,
To make her kind to me, and live contented,
That I shall find my kindness well returned,
And have no need to fight with my affections.
She (Late) hath found much fault with every room
Within my house; one was too big (She said)
Another was not furnished to her mind,
And so through all: all which I have altered.
Then here she hath a place (On my backside)
Wherein she loves to walk; and that (She said)
Had some ill smells about it. Now this walk
Have I (Before she knows it) thus perfumed
With herbs and flowers, and laid in divers places
(As 'twere on altars consecrate to her)
Perfumed gloves, and delicate chains of amber,
To keep the air in awe of her sweet nostrils:
This have I done, and this I think will please her.
Behold she comes.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Here's a sweet stink indeed:
What, shall I ever be thus crossed and plagued?
And sick of husband? O my head doth ache
As it would cleave asunder with these savours,
All my room's altered, and but one poor walk
That I delighted in, and that is made
So fulsome with perfumes, that I am feared
(My brain doth sweat so) I have caught the plague.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Why (Gentle wife) is now thy walk too sweet?
Thou saidst of late it had sour airs about it,
And foundest much fault, that I did not correct it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, and I did find fault sir?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Nay dear wife;
I know thou hast said thou hast loved perfumes,
No woman better.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Ay, long since perhaps,
But now that sense is altered: you would have me
(Like to a puddle or a standing pool)
To have no motion, nor no spirit within me.
No, I am like a pure and sprightly river,
That moves for ever, and yet still the same;
Or fire that burns much wood, yet still one flame.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: But yesterday, I saw thee at our garden
Smelling on roses and on purple flowers,
And since I hope the humour of thy sense
Is nothing changed.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Why those were growing flowers,
And these within my walk are cut and strewed.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: But yet they have one sent.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Ay, have they so?
In your gross judgement: if you make no difference
Betwixt the scent of growing flowers and cut ones,
You have a sense to taste lamp-oil, i'faith.
And with such judgement have you changed the chambers,
Leaving no room that I can joy to be in
In all your house: and now my walk and all
You smoke me from, as if I were a fox,
And long belike to drive me quite away:
Well walk you there, and I'll walk where I list.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: What shall I do? o I shall never please her.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Out on thee dotard, what star ruled his birth?
That brought him such a star? blind fortune still
Bestows her gifts on such as cannot use them:
How long shall I live, ere I be so happy,
To have a wife of this exceeding form?
Away with 'em, would I had broke a joint,
When I devised this that should so dislike her,
Away, be are all away.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: I do: for fear.
Ought that is there should like her. O this man
How cunningly he can conceal himself,
as though he loved? loved? nay honoured and adored?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Why, my sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: Sweet heart? o, better still:
And asking, why? wherefore? and looking strangely,
As if he were as white as innocence.
Alas, you're simple, you: you cannot change,
Look pale at pleasure, and then red with wonder:
No, no, not you: I did but cast an amorous eye even now
Upon a pair of gloves that somewhat liked me,
And straight he noted it, and gave command
All should be taken away.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Be they my bane then:
What sirrah, Fido, bring in those gloves again
You took from hence.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.l: 'Sbody sirrah, but do not:
Bring in no gloves to spite me: if you do —

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Ay me, most wretched; how am I misconstrued?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: O, how she tempts my heartstrings with her eye,
To knit them to her beauties, or to break?
What moved the heavens, that they could not make
Me such a woman? but a man; a beast,
That hath no bliss like to others. Would to God
(In wreak of my misfortunes) I were turned
To some fair water-nymph, that set upon
The deepest whirlpit of the ravenous seas,
My adamantine eyes might headlong hale
This iron world to me, and drown it all.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Behold, behold, the translated gallant.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, he is welcome.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p:
God save you brother, and sister, God save you sir; I have commendations for you out i'the country: (I wonder they take no knowledge of my suit:) mine uncle Sogliardo is in town; sister, methinks you are melancholy: why are you so sad? I think you took me for master Fastidius Briske
(Sister) did you not?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why should I take you for him?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay nothing, I was lately in master Fastidius his company, and methinks we are very like.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: You have a fair suit brother, God give you joy on't.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Faith good enough to ride in brother, I made it to ride in.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O, now I see the cause of his idle demand was his new suit.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Pray you good brother; try if you can change her mood.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I warrant you, let me alone. I'll put her out of her dumps. Sister, how like you my suit?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O you are a gallant in print now brother.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Faith, how like you the fashion? it's the last edition I assure you.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I cannot but like it to the desert.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Troth sister, I was fain to borrow these spurs, I ha' left my gown in gage for 'em, pray you lend me an angel.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Now beshrew my heart then.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Good truth I'll pay you again at my next exhibitior: I had but bore ten pound of my father, and it would not reach to put me wholly into the fashion.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I had spurs of mine own before, but they were not ginglers. Monsieur Fastidius will be here anon sister.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: You jest?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Never lend me penny more (While you live then) and that I'd be loath to say, in truth.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: When did you see him?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Yesterday, I came acquainted with him at sir Puntarvolo's: nay sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I fain would know of heaven now, why yond fool
Should wear a suit of satin? he? that rook?
That painted jay with such a deal of outside?
What is his inside trow? ha, ha, ha, ha, ha.
Good heaven give me patience,
a number of these popinjays there are,
Whom if a man confer, and but examine
Their inward merit, with such men as want;
Lord, lord, what things they are!

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Come, when will you pay me again now?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: O God sister.

div.stage: Enter Fastidius briske in a new suit.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Here comes another.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Save you signior Deliro: how dost thou sweet lady? Let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: How? A new suit? Ay me.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: And how does master Fastidius brisk?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith live in court signior Deliro, in grace I thank God, both of the noble masculine and feminine. I must speak with you in private by and by.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: When you please sir.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why look you so pale brother?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: 'Slid all this money is cast away now.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Ay, there's a newer edition come forth.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: 'Tis but my hard fortune: well, I'll have my suit changed, I'll go fetch my tailor presently, but first I'll devise a letter to my father. Have you any pen and ink sister?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: What would you do withal?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I would use it. 'slight and it had come but four days sooner the fashion.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: There was a countess gave me her hand to kiss today i' the presence: 'did me more good by Jesu, then, and yesternight sent her coach twice to my lodging, to intreat me accompany her, and my sweet mistress, with some two or three nameless ladies more: oh, I have been graced by 'em beyond all aim of affection: this her garter my dagger hangs in: and they do so commend and approve my apparel, with my judicious wearing of it, it's above wonder.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Indeed sir, 'tis a most excellent suit, and you do wear it as extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why I'll tell you now (In good faith) and by this chair, which (By the grace of God) I intend presently to sit in, I had three suits in one year, made three great ladies in love with me: I had other three, undid three gentlemen in imitation: and other three, got three other gentlemen, widows of three thousand pound a year.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O believe it sir; your good face is the witch, and your apparel the spells, that bring all the pleasures of the world into their circle.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Ah, the sweet grace of a courtier!

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well, would my father had left me but a good face for my portion yet; though I had shared the unfortunate wit that goes with it, I had not cared: I might have passed for somewhat i'the world then.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why, assure you signior, rich apparel has strange virtues: it makes him that hath it without means, esteemed for an excellent wit: he that enjoys it with means, puts the world in remembrance of his means: it helps the deformities of nature, and gives lustre to her beauties; makes continual holiday where it shines; sets the wits of ladies at work, that otherwise would be idle: furnisheth your two-shilling ordinary; takes possession of your stage at your new play; and enricheth your oars, as scorning to go with your scull.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Pray you sir, add this; it gives respect to your fools, makes many thieves, as many strumpets, and no fewer bankrupts.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Out, out, unworthy to speak where he breatheth.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: What's he, signior?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: A friend of mine, sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By heaven, I wonder at you citizens, what kind of creatures you are?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: That you can consort yourselves with such poor seam-rent fellows.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: He says true.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Sir I will assure you ( however you esteem of him) he's a man worthy of regard.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why? what has he in him of such virtue to be regarded? ha?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Marry he is a scholar sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Nothing else?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: And he is well travailed.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: He should get him clothes: I would cherish those good parts of travel in him, and prefer him to some nobleman of good place.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Sir, such a benefit should bind me to you for ever (In my friends right) and I doubt not but his desert shall more than answer my praise.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why, and he had good clothes, I'd carry him to the court with me tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: He shall not want for those sir, if gold and the whole city will furnish him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: You say well sir: faith signior Deliro, I am come to have you play the alchemist with me, and change the species of my land, into that mettle you talk of.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: With all my heart sir, what sum will serve you?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith some three or fourscore pound.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Troth sir I have promised to meet a gentleman this morning in Paul's, but upon my return I'll dispatch you.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I'll accompany you thither.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: As you please sir; but I go not thither directly.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I have no other designment in hand, and therefore as good go along.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p:
I were as good have a quartane fever follow me now, for I shall never be rid of him: (Bring me a cloak there one) still upon his grace at the court am I sure to be visited; I was a beast to give him any hope. Well, would I were in that I am out with him once, and — come signior Macilente, I must confer with you as we go. Nay dear wife, I beseech thee forsake these moods: look not like winter thus. Here take my keres, open my counting houses, spread all my wealth before
thee, choose any object that delights thee: if thou wilt eat the spirit of gold, and drink dissolved pearl in wine, 'tis for thee.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Nay my sweet wife.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Good lord! how you are perfumed in your terms and all: pray you leave us.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Come gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Adieu, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let thy words ever sound in mine ears, and thy graces disperse contentment through all my senses: oh, how happy is that lady above other ladies, that enjoys so absolute a gentleman to her servant! A countess give him her hand to kiss! ah foolish countess; he is a man worthy (If a woman may speak of a man's worth) to kiss the lips of an empress.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: What's master Fastidius gone, sister?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: I brother: he has a face like a cherubin.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: God's me, what luck's this? I have fetched my tailor and all: which way went he sister? can you tell?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Not I, in good faith: and he has a body like an angel.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: How long is't since he went?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why but e'en now: did you not meet him? and a tongue able to ravish any woman i'the earth.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: O, for god's sake (I'll please you for your pains:) but e'en now, say you? Come good sir: 'slid I had forgotten it too: sister, if anybody ask for mine uncle Sogliardo, they shall ha' him at the herald's office yonder by Paul's.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Well, I will not altogether despair: I have heard of a citizen's wife has been beloved of a courtier; and why not I? heigh ho: well, I will into my private chamber, lock the door to me, and think over all his good parts one after another.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Well, I doubt this last scene will endure some grievous torture.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: How? you fear 'twill be racked by some hard construction ▪

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Do not you?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: No in good faith: unless mine eyes could light me beyond sense, I see no reason why this should be more liable to the rack than the rest: you'll say perhaps the city will not take it well, that the merchant is made here to dote so perfectly upon his wife; and she again, to be so fastidiously affected, as she is?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: You have uttered my thought sir, indeed.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Why (By that proportion) the court might as well take offence at him we call the courtier, and with much more pretext, by how much the place transcends and goes before in dignity and virtue: but can you imagine that any noble or true spirit in the court (Whose sinewy, and altogether unaffected graces, very worthily express him a courtier) will make any exception at the opening of such an empty trunk as this brisk is? or think his own worth impeached by beholding his motley inside?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: No sir, I do not.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p:
No more, assure you, will any grave wise citizen, or modest matron, take the object of this folly in Deliro and his wife; but rather apply it as the foil to their own virtues: for that were to affirm, that a man writing of Nero, should mean all emperors: or speaking of Machiavell, comprehend all statesmen; or in our Sordido, all farmers; and so of the rest: than which, nothing can be uttered more malicious and absurd. Indeed there are a sort of these narrow-eyed decipherers, I confess, that will extort strange and abstruse meanings out of any subject, be it never so conspicuous and innocently delivered. But to such ( where'er they sit concealed) let them know, the author defies them, and their writing-tables; and hopes, no sound or safe judgement will infect itself with their contagious comments, who
(Indeed) come here only to pervert and poison the sense of what they hear, and for naught else.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Stay, what new mute is this that walks so suspiciously?

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter cavalier Shift, with two siquisses in his hand.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O, marry this is one, for whose better illustration; we must desire you to presuppose the stage, the middle isle in Paul's; and that, the West end of it.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: So sir: and what follows?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Faith a whole volume of humour, and worthy the unclasping

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: As how? what name do you give him first?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: He hath shift of name's sir: some call him apple John, some signior whiff, marry his main standing name is cavalier shift: the rest are but as clean shirts to his nature's

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: And what makes he in Paul's now?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Troth as you see, for the advancement of a siquis or two; wherein he has so varied himself, that if any one of 'em take, he may hull up and down i'the humorous world a little longer:

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: It seems then, he bears a very changing sail ▪

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O, as the wind sir: here comes more.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: This is rare, I have set up my bills without discovery.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: What? Signior whiff? what fortune has brought you into these West parts?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Troth signior, nothing but your rheum; I have been taking an ounce of tobacco hard by here with a gentleman, and I am come to spit private in Paul's. God save you sir.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: A dieu good signior whiff.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Master apple John? you are well met: when shall we sup together, and laugh and be fat with those good wenches? ha?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Faith sir, I must now leave you, upon a few humours and occasions: but when you please sir.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Farewell sweet apple John: I wonder there are no more store of gallants here ▪

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What be these two, signior?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Marry a couple sir, that are mere strangers to the whole scope of our play; only come to walk a turn or two i'this scene of Paul's by chance.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: Save you, good master Clouc.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Sweet master Orange.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: How? Clove, and Orange?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ay, and they are well met, for 'tis as dry an orange as ever grew: nothing but salutation, and oh God sir, and it pleases you to say so sir; one that can laugh at a jest for company with a most plausible, and extemporal grace; and some hour after in private ask you what it was: the other, monsieur Clove, is a more spiced youth: he will sit you a whole afternoon sometimes, in a booksellers shop, reading the Greek, Italian, and Spanish; when he understands not a word of either: if he had the tongues to his suits, he were an excellent linguist.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Do you hear this reported for certainty?

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: O good sir.

div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Carlo: two serving men following, one leading the dog.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sirrah, take my cloak: and you sir knave, follow me closer: if thou losest my dog, thou shalt die a dog's death; I will hang thee.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Tut, fear him not, he's a good lean slave, he loves a dog well I warrant him; I see by his looks, I: mass he's somewhat like him. 'sblood poison him, make him away with a crooked pin, or somewhat man; thou mayst have more security of thy life: and so sir, what? you ha' not put out your whole venture yet? ha' you?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
No, I do want yet some fifteen or sixteen hundred
pounds: but my lady (My wife) is out of her humour; she does not now go.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: No? how then?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Marry, I am now enforced to give it out, upon the return of myself, my dog, and my cat.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Your cat? where is she?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: My squire has her there in the bag: sirrah, look to her: how likest thou my change, Carlo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O, for the better sir; your cat has nine lives, and your wife ha' but one.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Besides, she will never be sea-sick, which will save me so much in conserves: when saw you signior Sogliardo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I came from him but now, he is at the herald's office yonder: he requested me to go afore and take up a man or two for him in Paul's, against his cognisance was ready.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What? has he purchased arms then?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ay, and rare ones too: of as many colours, as e'er you saw any fool's coat in your life ▪ I'll go look among yond bills, and I can fit him with legs to his arms.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: With legs to his arms! Good: I will go with you sir.

div.stage: They go to look upon the bills.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Come, let's walk in the mediterraneum: I assure you sir I am not the least respected among ladies; but let that pass: do you know how to go into the presence sir?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why, on my feet sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No, on your head sir: for 'tis that must bear you out, I assure you: as thus sir: you must first have an especial care so to wear your hat, that it oppress not confusedly this your predominant or foretop; because (When you come at the presence door) you may with once or twice stroking up your forehead thus, enter with your predominant perfect: that is, standing up stiff.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: As if one were frighted?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Ay sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p:
Which indeed, a true fear of your 〈◊〉 should
do, rather than gum water, or whites of eggs: is't not so sir?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: An ingenious observation: give me leave to crave your name sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: His name is Macilente sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good signior Macilente: if this gentleman, signior Deliro, furnish you (As he says he will) with clothes, I will bring you tomorrow by this time into the presence of the most divine and acute lady of the court: you shall see sweet silent rhetoric, and dumb eloquence speaking in her eye; but when she speaks herself, such an anatomy of wit, so sinewized and arterized, that 'tis the goodliest model of pleasure that ever was, to behold. O, she strikes the world into admiration of her; (Oh, o, o) I cannot express 'em believe me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O, your only admiration, is your silence, sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Before God Carlo, this is good; let's read 'em again: if there be any lady, or gentlewoman of good carriage, that is desirous to entertain (To her private uses) a young, straight, and upright gentleman, of the age of five, or six and twenty at the most: who can serve in the nature of a gentleman usher, and hath little legs of purpose, and a black satin suit of his own to go before her in: which suit (For the more sweetening) now lies in lavender: and can hide his face with her fan, if need require: or sit in the cold at the stair foot for her as well as another gentleman: let her subscribe her name and place, and diligent respect shall be given. This is above measure excellent: ha?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: No this, this: here's a fine slave.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
If this city, or the suburbs of the same, do afford any young gentleman, of the first, second, or third head, more or less, whose friends are but lately deceased, and whose lands are but new come to his hands, that (To be as exactly qualified as the best of our ordinary gallants are) is affected to entertain the most gentlemanlike use of tobacco: as first, to give it the most exquisite presume: then, to know all the delicate sweet forms for the assumption of it: as also the rare corollary and practice of the Cuban ebolition, Euripus, and whiff; which we
shall receive or take in here at London, and evaporate at Uxbridge, or farther, if it please him. If there be any such generous spirit, that is truly enamoured of these good faculties: may it please him, but (By a note of his hand) to specify the place, or ordinary where he uses to eat and lie, and most sweet attendance with tobacco, and pipes of the best sort shall be ministered: stet qvaeso candide lector ▪ why this is without parallel, this!

sp.speaker: Carlo
sp.p: Well, I'll mark this fellow for Sogliardo's use presently.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Or rather, Sogliardo for his use.

sp.speaker: Carlo.
sp.p: Faith either of 'em will serve, they are both good properties: I'll design the other a place too, that we may see him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: No better place than the mitre, that we may be spectators with you Carlo. Soft, behold, who enters here: signior Sogliardo! God save you.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Save you good sir Punt arvolo; your dog's in health sir I see: how now Carlo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: We have taken simple pains to choose you out followers here.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come hither signior.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Monsieur Orange, yond gallants observes us; prithee let's talk fustian a little and gull 'em: make 'em believe we are great scholars.

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: O lord sir.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Nay, prithee let's, by Jesu; you have an excellent habit in discourse.

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: It pleases you to say so sir.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: By this church you ha' la: nay come, begin: Aristotle in his daemonologia approves Scaliger for the best navigator in his time: and in his hypercritiques, he reports him to be heautontimoroumenos: you understand the Greek sir?

sp.speaker: Oreng.
sp.p: O God sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: For society's sake he does. O here be a couple of fine tame parrots.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Now sir, whereas the ingenuity of the time, and the soul's synderisis are but embryons in nature, added to the paunch of Esquiline, and the intervallum of the zodiac, besides the ecliptic line being optic, and not mental, but by the contemplative and theoric part there of, doth demonstrate to us the vegetable circumference, and the ventosity of the Tropicks, and whereas our intellectual or mincing capreal, (According to the metaphysics) as you may read in Plato's Histriomastix. You conceive me sir?

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: O lord sir.

sp.speaker: Clove.
sp.p: Then coming to the pretty animal, as reason long since is fled to animals you know, or indeed for the more modellizing or enamelling, or rather diamondizing of your subject, you shall perceive the hipothersis or galaxia, (Where of the meteors long since had their initial inceptions and notions) to be merely pythagorical, mathematical, and aristocratical: for look you sir, there is ever a kind of concinnity and species. Let us turn to our former discourse, for they mark us not.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Mass, yonder's the knight Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: And my cousin Sogliardo methinks .

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Ay, and his familiar that haunts him, the devil with a shining face.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Let 'em alone, observe 'em not.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay I will have him, I am resolute for that, by this parchment gentlemen, I have been so toiled among the heralds yonder, you will not believe, they do speak i'the strangest language, and give a man the hardest terms for his money, that ever you knew.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But ha' you arms? ha' your arms?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I'faith, I thank God I can write myself gentleman now, here's my patent, it cost me thirty pound by this breath.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: A very fair coat, well charged and full of armoury.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay, it has as much variety of colours in it, as you have seen a coat have, how like you the crest sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I understand it not well, what is't?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Marry sir, it is your boar without a head rampant.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: A boar without a head, that's very rare.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, and rampant too: troth I commend the herald's wit, he has deciphered him well: a swine without a head, without brain, wit, any thing indeed, ramping to gentility. You can blazon the rest signior? can you not?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Hey, I have it in writing here of purpose, it cost me two shillings the tricking.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Let's hear, let's hear.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: It is the most vile, foolish, absurd, palpable, and ridiculous escutcheon that ever this eye survised. Save you good monsieur Fastidius.

div.stage: They salute as they meet in the walk.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Silence good knight: on, on.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Gyrony of eight pieces, azure and gules, between three plates a chevron engrailed checky, or, vert and ermines; on a chief argent between two annulets, sables a boar's head Proper

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How's that? on a chief argent?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: On a chief argent, a boar's head proper between two annulets sables.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Sblood, it's a hog's cheek and puddings in a pewter field this

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How like you them signior?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Let the word be, not without mustard, your crest is very rare sir.

div.stage: Here they shift, Fast mixes with Punt. Carl. and Sogli. Deliro and Macilente, Clove and Orenge, four couple.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: A frying pan to the crest had had no fellow.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Entreat your poor friend to walk off a little signior, I will salute the knight.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Come, lap't up, lap't up.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: You are right well encountered sir, how does your fair dog?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: In reasonable state sir, what citizen is that you were consorted with? A merchant of any worth?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis signior Deliro sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Is it he? Save you sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Good sir Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O what copy of fool would this place minister to one endued with patience to observe it?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay look you sir, now you are a gentleman, you must carry a more exalted presence, change your mood and habit to a more austere form, be exceeding proud, stand upon your gentility, and scorn every man ▪ speak nothing humbly, never discourse under a nobleman, though you never saw him but riding to the star-chamber, it's all one. Love no man, trust no man, speak ill of no man to his face, nor well of any man behind his back. Salute fairly on the front, and wish 'em hanged upon the turn. Spread yourself upon his bosom publicly, whose heart you would eat in private. These be principles, think on 'em, I'll come to you again presently.

div.stage: Exit Car. Sogliardo mixes with punt. and fast.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Sirrah, keep close, yet not so close, thy breath will thaw my ruff.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O good cousin, I am a little busy, how does my niece, I am to walk with a knight here.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: 〈◊〉 is here, look you sir, that's the gentleman:

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: What he i'the blush-coloured satin?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Ay, he sir, though his suit blush, he blushes not: look you, that's the suit sir: I would have mine, such a suit without difference, such stuff, such a wing, such a sleeve, such a skirt, belly and all; therefore, pray you observe it. Have you a pair of tables?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why do you see sir? they say I am fantastical: why true, I know it, and I pursue my humour still in contempt of this censorious age: 'slight and a man should do nothing but what a sort of stale judgements about this town will approve in him, he were a sweet ass, I'd beg him i'faith: I never knew any more find fault with a fashion, than they that knew not how to put themselves into't. For mine own part, so I please mine own appetite, I am careless what the fusty world speaks of me, puh:

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Do you mark how it hangs at the knee there?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: I warrant you sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: For god's sake do, note all: do you see the collar sir ▪

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Fear nothing, it shall not differ in a stitch sir.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Pray God it do not, you'll make these linings serve? And help me to a chapman for the outside, will you?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: I'll do my best sir: you'll put it off presently:

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Ay, go with me to my chamber you shall have it, but make haste of it, for the love of Christ, for I'll sit i' my old suit, or else lie a-bed and read the Arcadia, till you have done.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, if ever you were struck with a jest, gallants, now, now ▪ I do usher the most strange piece of military profession, that ever was discovered in insula Paulina.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What is he for a creature?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A pimp, a pimp, that I have observed yonder, the rarest superficies of a humour; he comes every morning to empty his lungs in Paul's here, and offers up some five or six hecatombs of faces and sighs, and away again. Here he comes; nay walk, walk, be not seen to note him, and we shall have excellent sport.

div.stage: Walks by, and uses action to his-rapier.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: 'Slid he vented a sigh e'en now, I thought he would have blown up the church.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O you shall have him give a number of those false fires ere he depart.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: See now he is expostulating with his rapier, look, look.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Did you ever in your days observe better passion over a hilt?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Except it were in the person of a cutler's boy, or that the fellow were nothing but vapour, I should think it impossible.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: See, again, he claps his sword o'the head, as who should say, well, go to.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O violence, I wonder the blade can contain itself, being so provoked.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.l: With that, the moody squire thumped his breast,
And reared his eyes to heaven for revenge.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Troth, and you be gentlemen, let's make 'em friends, and take up the matter between his rapier and he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Nay, if you intend that, you must lay down the matter,
for this rapier (It seems) is in the nature of a hanger on ▪ and the good gentleman would happily be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By my faith, and 'tis to be suspected, I'll ask him.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: O here is rich stuff, for Christ sake, let us go,
A man would wish himself a senseless pillar,
Rather than view these monstrous prodigies:
Nil habet infelix paupertas durius in se,
Quam quod ridiculos homines facit.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: At your service.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Will you sell your rapier?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Sblood he is turned wild upon the question, he looks as he had seen a sergeant.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Sell my rapier? now God bless me.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: You asked me, if I would sell my rapier sir?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I did indeed.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Now lord have mercy upon me.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Amen I say still.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: 'Sblood sir, what should you behold in my face sir, that should move you (As they say sir) to ask me sir, if I would sell my rapier?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Nay (Let me pray you sir) be not moved: I protest I would rather have been silent than any way offensive, had I known your nature.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p:
Sell my rapier? God's lid: nay sir (For mine own part) as I am a man that has served in causes, or so, so I am not apt to injure any gentleman in the degree of falling foul, but: sell my rapier ▪ I will tell you sir, I have served with this foolish rapier, where some of us dare not appear in haste, I name no man: but let that pass; sell my rapier? Death to my lungs. This rapier sir, has travailed by my side sir, the best part of France and the low country: I have seen Vlishing, Brill, and the Hague with this rapier sir, in my lord of Leister's time: and (By God's will) he that should offer to disrapier me now, I would. — look you sir, you presume to be a gentleman of good sort,
and so likewise your friends here, if you have any disposition to travel, for the sight of service or so, one, two, or all of you, I can lend you letters to divers officers and commanders in the low countries, that shall for my cause do you all the good offices that shall pertain or belong to gentlemen of your — please you to show the bounty of your mind sir, to impart some ten groats or half a crown to our use, till our ability be of growth to return it, and we shall think ourself. — 'sblood, sell my rapier?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I pray you what said he signior, he's a proper man.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Marry he tells me, if I please to show the bounty of my mind, to impart some ten groats to his use or so.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Break his head, and give it him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I thought he had been playing on the Jews trump I.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: My rapier? no sir: my rapier is my guard, my defence, my revenue, my honour: (If you cannot impart be secret I beseech you) and I will maintain it, where there is a grain of dust or a drop of water: (Hard is the choice when the valiant must eat their arms or clem:) sell my rapier? no my dear, I will not be divorced from thee yet, I have ever found thee true as steel: and (You cannot impart sir) God save you gentlemen: (Nevertheless if you have a fancy to it sir.)

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: prithee away: is signior Deliro departed?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Have you seen a pimp outface his own wants better.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I commend him, that can dissemble them so well.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: True, and having no better a cloak for it than he has neither.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: God's precious, what mischievous luck is this: adieu gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Whither? in such haste, monsie ur Fastidius?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: After my merchant, signior Deliro sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O hinder him not, he may hap lose his tide, a good flounder i' faith.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: Hark you Sig. Whiff, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? Signior whiff?

div.stage: Oren. And Clou● call Shift aside.

sp.speaker: Oren.
sp.p: What was the difference between thou'st young gallant that's gone, and you sir.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p:
No difference: he would ha' given me five pound for
my rapier, and I refused it; that's all.

sp.speaker: Clou.
sp.p: O, was it no otherwise? we thought you had been upon some terms.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: No other than you saw sir.

sp.speaker: Clou.
sp.p: Adieu good master apple John.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? Whiff, and apple Joan too? Heart, what'll you say if this be the appendix, or label to both yond indentures?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: It may be.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Resolve us of it Janus, thou that lookest every way; or thou Hercules, that hast travailed all countries.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Nay Carlo, spend not time in invocations now; 'tis late.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Signior, here's a gentleman desirous of your name sir.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Sir, my name is cavalier shift: I am known sufficiently in this walk sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Shift? I heard your name varied e'en now, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: True sir, it pleases the world (As I am her excellent tobacconist) to give me the style of signior whiff: as I am a poor esquire about the town here, they call me master apple John: variety of good names does well sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, and good parts, to make those good names: out of which I imagine yond bills to be yours.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Sir, if I should deny the scriptures, I were worthy to be banished the middle I'll for ever.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I take your word sir: this gentleman has subscribed to 'em, and is most desirous to become your pupil; marry you must use expedition: signior Insulso Sogliardo, this is the professor.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: In good time sir, nay good sir house your head, do your profess these sleights in tobacco?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I do more than profess sir, and (If you please to be a practioner) I will undertake in one fortnight to bring you, that you shall take it plausibly in any ordinary, theatre, or the tiltyard if need be; the most popular assembly that is.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: But you cannot bring him to the whiff so soon?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Yes as soon sir; he shall receive the 1, 2, and 3 whiff, if it please him, and (Upon the receipt) take his horse, drink his three cups of Canary, and expose one at Hounslow, a second at Stanes, and a third at Bagshot.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Baw-waw.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: You will not serve me sir, will you ▪ I'll give you more than countenance.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me sir, I do scorn to serve any man.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Who? he serve? 'sblood he keeps high men, and low men, he; he has a fair living at Fullam.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: But in the nature of a fellow, I'll be your follower if you please.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Sir you shall stay and dine with me, and if we can agree, we'll not part in haste: I am very bountiful to men of quality. Where shall we go signior.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Your mitre is your best house.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I can make this dog take as many whiffs as I list, and he shall retain or efume them at my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: By your patience, follow me fellows.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Sir Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Pardon me, my dog shall not eat in his company for a million.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay be not you amazed signior whiff, whate'er that stiffnecked gentleman says.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: No, for you do not know the humour of the dog as we do: where shall we dine Carlo? I would fain go to one of these ordinaries now I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: So you may, were you never at none yet?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: No faith, but they say there resorts your most choice gallants.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: True, and the fashion is, when any stranger comes in amongst 'em, they all stand up and stare at him, as he were some unknown beast brought out of Afric, but that'll be helped with a good adventurous face, you must be impudent enough, sit down and use no respect, when any thing's propounded above your capacity, smile at it, make two or three faces, and 'tis excellent, they'll think you have travailed: though you argue a whole day in silence thus, and discourse in nothing but laughter, 'twill pass. Only (Now and then) give fire, discharge a good full oath, and offer a great wager, 'twill be admirable.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I warrant you, I am resolute, come good signior, there's a poor French crown for your ordinary.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: It comes well, for I had not so much as the least portcullis of come before.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: I travel with another objection signior, which I fear will be enforced against the author, ere I can be delivered of it

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: What's that sir?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: That the argument of his comedy might have been of some other nature, as of a Duke to be in love with a countess, and that countess to be in love with the Duke's son, and the son to love the lady's waiting maid: some such cross wooing, with a clown to their servingman, better than to be thus near and familiarly allied to the time.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: You say well, but I would fain hear one of these autumn - judgements define once, quid sit comoedia? if he cannot, let him content himself with Cicero's definition (Till he have strength to propose to himself a better) who would have a comedy to be imitatio vitae, speculum consuetudinis, imago veritatis, a thing throughout pleasant and ridiculous, and accommodated to the correction of manners: if the maker have failed in any particle of this, they may worthily tax him, but if not, why; be you (That are for them) silent, as I will be for him; and give way to the actors.

div.head: Scaena secunda
div.stage: Enter Sordido with a halter about his neck.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: Nay gods-precious, if the weather and the season be so respectless, that beggars shall live as well as their betters; and that my hunger and thirst for riches, shall not make them hunger and thirst with poverty; that my sleeps shall be broken, and their hearts not broken; that my coffers shall be full, and yet care; theirs empty, and yet merry: 'tis time that a cross should bear flesh and blood, since flesh and blood cannot bear this cross.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What will he hang himself?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Faith I, it seems his prognostication has not kept touch with him, and that makes him despair.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Be shrew me, he will be out of his humour then indeed.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: Tut, these star-monger knaves, who would trust 'em? one says, dark and rainy, when 'tis as clear as crystal; another says, tempestuous blasts, and storms, and 'twas as calm as a milk bowl; here be sweet rascals for a man to credit his whole fortunes with: you sky-staring cocks combs you: you fat brains, out upon you; you are good for nothing but to sweat nightcaps and make rug-gowns dear: you learned men, and have not a legion of devils, a vostre service: a vostre service? By heaven I think I shall die a better scholar than they, but soft, how now sirrah.

div.stage: Enter a hind with a letter.

sp.speaker: Hind.
sp.p: Here's a letter come from your son sir.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p:
From my son sir? what would my son sir? some good news no doubt.
The letter.
Sweet and dear father, (Desiring you first to send me your blessing, which is more worth to me than gold or silver) I desire you likewise to be advertised, that this Shrovetide (Contrary to custom) we use always to have revels; which is indeed dancing, and makes an excellent show in truth; especially if we gentlemen be well attired, which our seniors note, and think the better of our fathers, the better we are maintained, and that they shall know if they come up, and have any thing to do in the law: therefore good father, these are (For your own sake as well as mine) to re-desire you, that you let me not want that which is fit for the setting up of our name in the honourable volume of gentility, that I may say to our calumnators with Tully, ego sum ortus domus meae, tu occasustvae. And thus (Not doubting of your fatherly benevolence) humbly ask you blessing, and pray God to bless you.Yours, if his own.how's this; yours, if his own? is he not my son, except he be his own son. Belike this is some new kind of subscription the gallants use. Well, wherefore dost thou stay knave?
Away: go.

div.p: Here's a letter indeed; revels? and benevolence? is this a weather to send benevolence? or is this a season to revel in? Slid the devil and all takes part to vex me I think: this letter would never have come now else, now, now, when the sun shines, and the air thus clear. Soul if this hold, we shall shortly have an excellent crop of corn spring out of the high ways, the streets, and houses of the town will be hid with the rankness of the fruits that grow there in spite of good husbandry. Go to I'll prevent the sight of it, come as quickly as it can, I will prevent the sight of it. I have this remedy heaven: stay; I'll try the pain thus a little, oh, nothing, nothing. Well now: shall my son gain a benevolence by my death ▪ or anybody be the better for my gold or so forth: no alive, I kept it from 'em, and (Dead) my ghost shall walk about it and preserve it, my son and daughter shall starve ere they touch it, I have hid it as deep as hell from the sight of heaven, and to it I go now.
div.stage: Enter rustici, 5 or 6, one after another.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: Ay me, what pitiful sight is this? help, help, help ▪

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: How now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: O here's a man has hanged himself, help to get him again.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Hanged himself? 'slid carry him afore a justice, 'tis chance medley on my word.

sp.speaker: Rust. 3
sp.p: How now, what's here to do?

sp.speaker: Rust. 4
sp.p: How comes this?

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: One has executed himself contrary to the order of law, and by my consent he shall answer't.

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Would he were in case to answer it.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: Stand by, he recovers, give him breath.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Mass, 'twas well you went the footway neighbour.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: Ay, and I had not cut the halter.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: How? cut the halter? Ay me, I am undone, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Marry if you had not been undone, you had been hanged I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.p: You threadbare horsebread eating rascals, if you would needs have been meddling, could you not have untied it, but you must cut it? and in the midst too? Ay me.

sp.speaker: Rust. 1
sp.p: Out on me, 'tis the caterpillar Sordido; how cursed are the poor, that the viper was blessed with this good fortune?

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Nay how accursed are thou, that art cause to the curse of the poor?

sp.speaker: Rust. 3
sp.p: Ay, and to save so wretched a caitiff.

sp.speaker: Rust. 4
sp.p: Cursed be thy fingers that loosed him.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Some desperate fury possess thee, that thou mayst hang thyself too.

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Never mayest thou be saved, that saved so damned a monster.

sp.speaker: Sord.
sp.l: What curses breath these men? how have my deeds
Made my looks differ from another man's,
That they should thus detest, and loathe my life?
Out on my wretched humour, it is that
Makes me thus monstrous in true humane eyes.
Pardon me (Gentle friends) I'll make fair mends
For my foul errors passed and twentyfold
Restore to all men, what with wrong I robbed them:
My barns and garners shall stand open still
To all the poor that come, and my best grain
Be made alms-bread to feed half-famished mouths.
Though hitherto amongst you I have lived
Like an unsavoury muck hill to myself,
Yet now my gathered heaps being spread abroad,
Shall turn to better, and more fruitful uses.
Bless then this man, curse him no more for saving
My life and soul together. O how deeply
The bitter curses or the poor do pierce!
I am by wonder changed; come in with me
And witness my repentance: now I prove,
"No life is blessed, that is not graced with love.

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: O miracle! see when a man has grace.

sp.speaker: Rust. 3
sp.p: Had't not been pity so good a man should have been cast away?

sp.speaker: Rust. 2
sp.p: Well, I'll get our clerk put his conversion in the chronicle.

sp.speaker: Rust. 4
sp.p: Do, for I warrant him he's a virtuous man.

sp.speaker: Rust.
sp.p: O god how he wept if you marked it: did you see how the tears trilled?

sp.speaker: Rust. 5
sp.p: Yes believe me; like master vicar's bowls upon the green, for all the world.

sp.speaker: 3 or 4
sp.p: O neighbour, god's blessing your heart neighbour, 'twas a good grateful deed.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: How now Mitis? what's that you consider so seriously?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Troth, that which doth essentially please me: the warping condition of this green and soggy multitude: but in good faith signior, your author hath largely outstripped my expectation in this scene, I will liberally confess it. For when I saw Sordido so desperately intended, I thought I had had a hand of him then.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: What? you supposed he should have hung himself indeed?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: I did; and had framed my objection to it ready, which may yet be very fitly urged, and with some necessity: for though his purposed violence lost th'effect, and extended not to death, yet the intent and horror of the object was more than the nature of a comedy will in any sort allow.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: I? what think you of Plautus in his come die called Cistellaria there? where he brings in Alcesimarchus with a drawn sword ready to kill himself, and as he is e'en fixing his breast upon it, to be restrained from his resolved outrage by silenium and the bawd: is not his authority of power to give our scene approbation?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p:
Sir, I have this (Your only) evasion left me, to say, 〈◊〉 think it be so indeed, your memory is happier than mine: but I wonder
what engine he will use to bring the rest out of their humours?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: That will appear anon, never preoccupy your imagination withal. Let your mind keep company with the scene still, which now removes itself from the country to the court. Here comes Macilente and signior brisk freshly suited, lose not yourself, for now the epitasis or busy part of our subject is in action.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Macilente, Briske, Cinedo, with tobacco.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Well now signior Macilente, you are not only welcome to the court, but also to my mistress with drawing chamber: boy get me some tobacco, I'll but go in, and show I am here, and come to you presently sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What's that he said? by heaven I marked him not,
My thoughts, and I were of another world;
I was admiring mine own outside here,
To think what privilege and palm it bears
Here in the court: be a man never so vile
In wit, in judgement, manners, or what else;
If he can purchase but a silken cover,
He shall not only pass, but pass regarded:
Whereas let him be poor and meanly clad,
Though never so richly parted; you shall have
A fellow (That knows nothing but his beef
Or how to rinse his clammy guts in beer)
Will take him by the shoulders or the throat,
And kick him down the stairs, such is the state
Of virtue in bad clothes, ha, ha, ha, ha,
That raiment should be in such high request?
How long should I be ere I should put off
To my lord chancellor's tomb, or the shrieve's posts?
By heaven (I think) a thousand thousand year,
His gravities, his wisdom, and his faith,
To my dread sovereign (Graces that survive him)
These I could well endure to reverence,
but not his tomb, no more than I'll commend
The chapel organ for the guilt without,
Or this base viol for the varnished face.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: In faith I have made you stay somewhat long sir, but is my tobacco ready boy?

sp.speaker: Cinc.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Give me, my mistress is upon coming, you shall see her presently sir, (Tab.) you'll say you never accosted a more piercing wit. This tobacco is not dried boy, or else the pipe's defective. O, your wits of Italy are nothing comparable to her, her brain's a very quiver of jests, and she does dart them abroad with that sweet loose and judicial aim that you would — here she comes sir.

div.stage: Enter Saviolina, and goes in again.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: 'Twas time, his invention had been bogged else.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Give me my fan there.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: How now monsieur Briske?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: A kind of affectionate reverence strikes me with a cold shivering ( methinks .)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I like such tempers well, as stand before their mistresses with fear and trembling, and before their maker like impudent mountains.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By Jesu, I'd spend twenty pound my vaulting horse stood here now, she might see me do but one trick?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why does she love activity ▪

sp.speaker: Cine.
sp.p: Or if you had but your long stockings on to be dancing a galliard, as she comes by.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I either. O these stirring humours make ladies mad with desire, she comes. My good genius embolden me, boy the pipe quickly.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What? will he give her music?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: A second good morrow to my fair mistress.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Fair servant, I'll thank you a day hence, when the date of your salutation comes forth.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: How like you that answer? is't not admirable?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I were a simple courtier, if I could not admire trifles sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Troth sweet lady I shall (Tab.) be prepared to give you thanks for those thanks, and (Tab.) study more officious and obsequious regards (Tab.) to your fair beauties: (Tab.) mend the pipe boy.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I never knew tobacco taken as a parenthesis before.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Fore God (Sweet lady) believe it, I do honour the meanest rush in this chamber for your love.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Ay, you need not tell me that sir, I do think you do prize a rush before my love.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Is this the wonder of nations?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O, by Jesu pardon me, I said for your love, by this light; but it is the accustomed sharpness of your ingenuity sweet mistress to — mass your viol's new strung methinks .

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Ingenuity; I see his ignorance will not suffer him to slander her; which he had done most notably, if he had said wit for ingenuity, as he meant it.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: By the soul of music lady (Hum, hum.)

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Would we might hear it once.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I do more adore and admire your (Hum, hum) predominant perfections then (Hum, hum) ever I shall have power and faculty to express (Hum.)

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Upon the viol de gamba you mean?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: It's miserably out of tune, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Nay rather by the fingers.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: It makes good harmony with her wit.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Sweet lady tune it. Boy some tobacco.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Tobacco again? he does court his mistress with very exceeding good changes.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Signior Macilente, you take none sir? (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: No, unless I had a mistress signior, it were a great indecorum for me to take tobacco.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: How like you her wit? (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Her ingenuity is excellent sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
You see the subject of her sweet fingers there? (Tab.) ▪ o she tickles it so, that (Tab.) she makes it laugh most
divinely; (Tab.) I'll tell you a good jest now, and yourself shall say it's a good one: I have wished myself to be that instrument (I think) a thousand times, and not so few, by heavens (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Not unlike sir: but how? to be cased up and hung by on the wall?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O, no sir, to be in use I assure you; as your judicious eyes may testify. (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Here servant, if you will play, come.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Instantly sweet lady (Tab.) In good faith here's most divine tobacco.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Nay, I cannot stay to dance after your pipe.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good, nay dear lady stay: by this sweet smoke, I think your wit be all fire: (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: And he's the salamander that lives by it.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Is your tobacco perfumed sir? that you swear by the sweet smoke?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Still more excellent: (Before God, and these bright heavens) I think (Tab.) you are made of ingenuity, I (Tab.)

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: True, as your discourse is: oh abominable!

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Will your ladyship take any?

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: O, peace I pray you; I love not the breath of a woodcock's head.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Meaning my head, lady?

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Not altogether so sir; but (As it were fatal to their follies that think to grace themselves with taking tobacco, when they want better entertainment) you see your pipe bears the true form of a woodcock's head.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O admirable simile!

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: 'Tis best leaving of you in admiration, sir ▪

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Are these the admired lady-wits, that having so good a plainsong, can run no better division upon it. S'heart, all her jests are of the stamp march was fifteen years ago. Is this the comet monsieur Fastidius, that your gallants wonder at so?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Heart of a gentleman to neglect me afore presence thus: sweet sir, I beseech you be silent in my disgrace, by Jesu, I never was in so vile a humour in my life, and her wit was at the flood too, report it not for a million good sir; let me be so far endeared to your love.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What follows next signior Cordatus? this gallants humour is almost spent methinks , it ebbs apace, with this contrary breath of his mistress.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O, but it will flow again for all this, till there come a general drought of humour among all our actors, and then I fear not but his will fall as low as any. See who presents himself here:

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What, i'the old case?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: I'faith, which makes it the more pitiful, you understand where the scene is?

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why are you so melancholy brother?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: I am not melancholy I thank you sister.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Why are you not merry then? there are but two of us in all the world, and if we should not be comforts to one another, God help us.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Faith, I cannot tell sister, but if a man had any true melancholy in him, it would make him melancholy, to see his yeomanly father cut his neighbour's throats to make his son a gentleman: and yet when he has cut 'em, he will see his son's throat cut too, ere he make him a true gentleman indeed, before death cut his own throat ▪ I must be the first head of our house, and yet he will not give me the head, till I be made so. Is any man termed a gentleman that is not always i'the fashion? I would know but that.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p:
If you be melancholy for that brother, I think I have
as much cause to be melancholy, as one; for I'll be sworn I live as little in the fashion, as any woman in London. By the bible of heaven (Beast that I am to say it) I have not one friend i'the world besides my husband. When saw you master Fastidius Briske, brother?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: But a while since sister, I think, I know not well in truth. By god's lid I could sight with all my heart methinks .

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Nay good brother, be not resolute.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I sent him a letter, and he writes me no answer neither.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O sweet Fastidius brisk, oh fine courtier, thou a● he mak'st me sigh and say, how blessed is that woman that hath a courtier to her husband? and how miserable a dame she is that hath neither husband nor friend in the court: oh sweet Fastidius, oh fine courtier. How comely he bows him in his courtesy? how full he hits a woman betwixt the lips when he kisses? how upright he sits at the table? how daintily he carves? how sweetly he talks, and tells news of this lord, and of that lady? how cleanly he wipes his spoon at every spoonful of any white-meat he eats, and what a near case of picktooths he carries about him still? O sweet Fastidius, oh fine courtier!

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: See yonder she is gentlemen, now (As ever you'll bear the name of musicians) touch your instruments sweetly, she has a delicate ear, I tell you, play not a false note I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Music.
sp.p: Fear not signior Deliro.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O begin, begin, some sprightly thing; lord, how my imagination labours with the success of it: well said, good i'faith, heaven grant it please her, I'll not be seen, for then she'll be sure to dislike it.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Hey da, this is excellent, I'll lay my life this is my husband's dotage, I thought so, nay never play peekaboo with me, I know you do nothing but study how to anger me sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Anger thee, sweet wife? why didst thou not send for musicians to supper last night thyself?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: To supper sir? now come up to supper I beseech you: as though there were no difference between supper time when folks should be merry, and this time when they would be melancholy? I would never take upon me to take a wife, if I had no more judgement to please her.

sp.speaker: Deli
sp.p: Be pleased sweet wife, and they shall ha' done: and would to Christ my life were done, if I can never please thee.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: God save you lady; where is master Deliro?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Here, master Macilente: you're welcome from the court sir; no doubt you have been graced exceedingly of master Briske's mistress, and the rest of the ladies for his sake?

sp.speaker: Mac●.
sp.l: Alas, the poor fantastic, he's scarce known
To any lady there: and those that know him,
Know him the simplest man of all they know:
Deride, and play upon his amorous humours,
Though he but apishly doth imitate
The gallant courtiers, kissing lady's pumps,
Holding the cloth for them, praising their wits,
And servilely observing every one,
May do them pleasure: fearful to be seen
With any man (Though he be never so worthy)
That's not in grace with some that are the greatest.
Thus courtiers do, and these he counterfeits,
But sets not such a sightly carriage
Upon their vanities, as they themselves;
And therefore they despise him: for indeed
He's like a zany to a tumbler,
That tries tricks after him to make men laugh.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Here's an unthankful spiteful wretch: the good gentleman vouchsafed to make him his companion (Because my husband put him into a few rags) and now see how the unrude rascal backbites him.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Is he no more graced amongst 'em than? say you?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith like a pawn at chess, fills up a room, that's all.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O monster of men! can the earth bear such an envious caitiff?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Well, I repent me I e'er credited him so much: but (Now I see what he is, and that his masking viz or is of) I'll forbear him no longer: all his lands are mortgaged to me, and forfeited: besides, I have bonds of his in my hand for the receipt of now xx pound, now xxx, now xxv: still as he has had a fan but wagged at him, he would be in a new suit. Well, I'll salute him by a sergeant, the next time I see him i'faith, I'll suit him.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why, you may soon see him sir, for he is to meet signior Puntarvolo at a notary's by the exchange presently, where he means to take up upon return.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Now out upon thee Judas; canst thou not be content to backbite thy friend, but thou must betray him? wilt thou seek the undoing of any man? and of such a man too? and will you sir get your living by the counsel of traitors?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Dear wife, have patience.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: The house wil fall, the ground will open, and swallow us: I'll not bide here for all the gold an silver in heaven.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O good Macilente, let's follow and appease her, or the peace of my life is at an end.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Now pease, and not peace feed that life, whose head hangs so heavily over a woman's manger.

div.stage: Enter fallacerunning, at another door, and claps it too.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Help me brother: God's body and you come here, I'll do myself a mischief.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Nay, hear me sweet wife, unless thou wilt have mec go, I will not go.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p:
Tut, you shall never ha' that vantage of me, to say you are undone by me: I'll not bid you stay, I. Brother, sweet brother, here's four angels, I'll give you towards your suit; for the love of Jesu, and as ever you came of Christen creature, make haste to the water side (You know where master Fastidius uses to land) and give him warning of my husband's intent; and tell him of that lean rascal's treachery: oh Jesu,
how my flesh rises at him? nay, sweet brother make haste; you may say I would have writ to him, but that the necessity of the time would not suffer it: he cannot choose but take it extraordinarily from me: and commend me to him, good brother: say I sent you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Let me see; these four angels: and then forty shillings more I can borrow on my gown in Fetter-lane: well, I will go presently, say on my suit, pay as much money as I have, and swear myself into credit with my tailor for the rest.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Deliro, with Macilente, speaking as they pass over the stage.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O, on my soul you wrong her, 〈◊〉, though she be froward, yet I know she is honest.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well, then have I no judgement; would nay woman (But one that were wild in her affections) have broke out into that immodest and violent passion against her husband? or is't possible —

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: If you love me, forbear; all the arguments i'the world shall never wrest my heart to believe it.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: How like you the deciphering of his dotage?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, strangely; and of the others envy too, that labours so seriously to set debate betwixt a man and his wife, stay, here comes the knight adventurer.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Ay, and his scrivener with him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I wonder monsieur Fastidius comes not! but notary, if thou please to draw the indentures the while, I will give thee the theory.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: With all my heart sir; and I'll fall in hand with 'em presently.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Well then, first; the sum is to be understood.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Next, our several appellations, and character of my dog and cat must be known: show him the cat sirrah.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Then, that the intended point, is the Turks court in Constantinople: the time limited for our return, a year: and that if either of us miscarry, the whole venture is lost. These are general; conceivest thou? or if either of us turn Turk.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Now for particulars: that I may make my travails by sea or land, to my best liking: and that (Hiring a coach for myself) it shall be lawful for my dog and cat to ride with me in the said coach.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That I may choose to give my dog or cat fish, for fear of bones, or any other nutriment, that (By the judgement of the most authentical physicians where I travail) shall be thought dangerous.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That (After the receipt of his money) he shall neither in his own person, nor any other, either by direct or indirect means; as magic, witchcraft, or other such exotic arts, attempt, practice, or complot any thing, to the prejudice of me, my dog, or my cat: neither shall I use the help of any such sorceries or enchantments; as unctions, to make our skins impenetrable, or to travail invisible by virtue of a powder, or a ring, or to hang any three-forked charm about my dog's neck, secretly conveyed into his collar: understand you? but that all be performed, sincerely, without fraud or imposture.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That (For testimony of the performance) myself am to bring thence a Turks mustachio, my dog a hare's lip, and my cat the train or tail of a rat.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: 'Tis done sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: 'Tis said sir, not done sir, but forward. That upon my return and landing on the tower wharf with the aforesaid testimony, I am to receive five for one, according to the proportion of the sums putforth.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Pu●●.
sp.p: Provided, that if before our departure or setting forth, either myself, or these be visited with sickness, or any other casual event, so that the whole course of the adventure be hindered thereby; that then, he is to return, and I am to receive the prenominated proportion, upon fair and equal terms.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: Very good sir; is this all?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: It is all sir: and dispatch them good notary.

sp.speaker: Notary
sp.p: As fast as is possible sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: O Carlo, welcome: saw you monsieur brisk?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not I: did he appoint you to meet here?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Ay, and I muse he should be so tardy: he is to take an hundred pounds of me in venture, if he maintain his promise.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is his hour passed?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Not yet, but it comes on apace.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Tut, be not jealous of him; he will sooner break all the ten commandments, than his hour; upon my life in such a case trust him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: methinks Carlo, you look very smooth? ha?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why I come but now from a hothouse, I must needs look smooth.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: From a hothouse?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ay, do you make a wonder on't? why it's your only physic. Let a man sweat once a week in a hothouse, and be well rubbed and froted with a good plump juicy wench, and sweet linen, he shall never ha'the pox.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What? the French pox?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The French pox! our pox: 'sblood we have 'em in as good form as then man: what?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
Let me perish, but thou art a villain: was your new-created
gallant there with you? Sogliardo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O purpose, hang him, no: he's a lieger at horn's ordinary yonder: his villainous Ganymede and he ha' been droning a tobacco pipe there, ever sin' yesterday noon.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Who? Signior tripartite, that would give my dog the whiffse?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ay, he: they have hired a chamber and all private to practise in, for the making of the patoun, the receipt reciprocal, and a number of other mysteries, not yet extant ▪ I brought some dozen or twenty gallants this morning to view 'em (As you'd do a piece of perspective) in at a keyhole; and there we might see Sogliardo sit in a chair, holding his snout up like a sow under an appletree, while th'other opened his nostrils with a poking-stick, to give the smoke a more free delivery. They had spit some three or fourscore ounces between 'em, afore we came away.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How! spit three or fourscore ounces?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, and preserved it in porringers, as a barber does his blood when he pricks a vein.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Out pagan; how dost thou prick the vain of thy friend?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Friend? Is there any such foolish thing i'the world? ha? 'slid I never relished it yet.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Thy humour is the more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: No not a whit signior: tut, a man must keep time in all: I can oil my tongue when I meet him next, and look with a good slick forehead; 'twill take away all soil of suspicion, and that's enough: what Lynceus can see my heart? Pish, the title of a friend, it's a vain idle thing, only venerable among fools: you shall not have one that has any opinion of wit affect it.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Save you good sir Puntarvolo.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Signior Deliro! Welcome.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Pray you sir, did you see master Fastidius brisk? I heard he was to meet your worship here.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: You heard no figment s●●, I do expect him every minute my watch strikes.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: In good time sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: There's a fellow now, looks like one of the patricians of Sparta, marry his wit's after ten i'the hundred. A good bloodhound, a close mouthed dog, he follows the scent well, marry he's at a fault now methinks .

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I should wonder at that creature is free from the danger of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Carl.
