sp.p: O I cannot abide these limbs of satin, or rather Sathan indeed, that will walk (Like the children of darkness) all day in a melancholy shop, with their pockets full of blanks, ready to swallow up as many poor unthrifts, as come within the verge.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: So: and what hast thou for him that is with him now?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O (Damn me) immortality, I'll not meddle with him, the pure element of fire, all spirit, extraction.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How Carlo? ha, what is he man?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: A scholar, Macilente, do you not know him? A lank rawboned anatomy, he walks up and down like a charged musket, no man dares encounter him: that's his rest there.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: His rest? why has he a forked head?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Pardon me, that's to be suspended, you are too quick, too apprehensive.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Troth (Now I think on't) I'll defer it till some other time.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Gods-precious, not by any means signior, you shall not lose this opportunity, he will be here presently now.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Yes faith Macilente, 'tis best. For look you sir, I shall so exceedingly offend my wife in't, that —

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Your wife? now for shame lose these thoughts, and become the master of your own spirits. Should I (If I had a wife) suffer myself to be thus passionately carried (To and for) with the stream of her humort and neglect my deepest affairs, to serve her affections? 'sblood I would geld myself first.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O but signior, had you such a wife as mine is, you would —

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p:
Such a wife: now God hate me sir, if ever I discerned
any wonder in your wife yet, with all the speculation I have: I have seen some that ha' been thought fairer than she, in my time; and I have seen those, ha' not been altogether so tall, esteemed proper women; and I have seen less noses grow upon sweeter faces, that have done very well too in my judgement: but in good faith signior for all this, the gentlewoman is a good pretty proud hard-favoured thing, marry not so peerlessely to be doted upon, I must confess: nay be not angry.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Well sir ( however you please to forget yourself) I have not deserved to be thus played upon, but henceforth, pray you forbear my house, for I can but faintly endure the savour of his breath at my table, that shall thus jade me for my courtesies.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Nay then signior, let me tell you, your wife is no proper woman by Jesu, and I suspect her honesty, that's more, which you may likewise suspect (If you please:) do you see? I'll urge you to nothing against your appetite, but if you please, you may suspect it.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Good sir? Now horn upon horn pursue thee, thou blind egregious dotard.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O you shall hear him speak like envy. Signior Macilente, you saw monsieur brisk lately? I heard you were with him at the court.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I Buffone, I was with him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And how is he respected there? (I know you'll deal ingeniously with us) is he made of amongst the sweeter sort of gallants?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Faith I, his civet and his casting glass,
Have helped him to a place amongst the rest,
And there his seniors give him good sleight looks,
After their garb, smile, and salute in French
With some new compliment.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What is this all?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Why say, that they should show the frothy fool,
Such grace as they pretend comes from the heart,
He had a mighty windfall out of doubt.
Why all their graces are not to do grace
To virtue, or desert: but to ride both
With their guilt spurs quite breathless from themselves.
'Tis now esteemed precisianism in wit;
And a disease in nature to be kind
Towards desert, to love, or seek good names:
Who feeds with a good name? who thrives with loving?
Who can provide feast for his own desires,
With serving others? ha, ha, ha:
'Tis folly by our wisest worldlings proved
(If not to gain by love) to be beloved.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How like you him? is't not a good spiteful slave? ha?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Shrewd, shrewd.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Damn me, I could eat his flesh now: divine sweet villain.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay, prithee leave: what's he there?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Who? this i'the starched beard? it's the dull stiff knight Puntarvolo man; he's to travail now presently: he has a good knotty wit, marry he carries little on't out of the land with him.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: How then?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: He puts it forth in venture, as he does his money; upon the return of a dog and cat.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Is this he?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, this is he; a good tough gentleman: he looks like a chine of brawn at Shrovetide, out of date, and ready to take his leave: or a dry poule of ling upon Easter-eve, that has furnished the table all lent, as he has done the city this last vacation.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Come, you'll never leave your stabbing similes: I shall ha' you aiming at me with 'em by and by, but —

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, renounce me then: pure, honest, good devil, I love thee above the love of women; I could e'en melt in admiration of thee now: god's so, look here man; sir Dagonet and his squire.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p:
Save you my dear Gallanto's. nay, come approach,
good cavalier: prithee (Sweet knight) know this gentleman, he's one that it pleases me to use as my good friend and companion; and therefore do him good offices: I beseech you gentles, know him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sir (For signior Sogliardo's sake) let it suffice, I know you.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Why by Jesu, I thank you knight, and it shall suffice. Hark you sir Puntarvolo, you'd little think it; he's as resolute a piece of flesh as any's i'the world.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Indeed sir?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Upon my gentility sir: Carlo, a word with you; do you see that same fellow there?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What? Cavalier shift?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O, you know him; cry you mercy: before God, I think him the tallest man living within the walls of Europe.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: The walls of Europe! take heed what you say signior, europe's a huge thing within the walls.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Tut, (And 'twere as huge again) I'd justify what I speak. 'slid he swaggered e'en now in a place where we were: I never saw a man do it more resolute.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay indeed swaggering is a good argument of resolution. Do you hear this, signior?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Ay, to my grief. O that such muddy flags
For every drunken flourish, should achieve
The name of manhood; whilst true perfect valour
(Hating to show itself) goes by despised.
'Sblood, I doc know now (In affair just cause)
I dare do more than he; a thousand times:
Why should not they take knowledge of this? ha?
And give my worth allowance before his?
Because I cannot swagger. Now the pox
Light on your Pickt-hatch prowess.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p:
Why I tell you sir, he has been the only bid-stand that ever was, kept Newmarket, Salisbury plain, Hockley i'the hole, Gadshill; all the high places of any request: he has had his mares and his geldings he, ha' been worth forty, threescore,
a hundred pound a horse, would ha' sprung you over hedge and ditch like your greyhound: he has done five hundred robberies in his time, more or less, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: What? and scaped?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Scaped! i'faith I: he has broken the jail when he has been in irons, and irons; and been out, and in again; and out, and in; forty times and not so few, he.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: A fit trumpet to proclaim such a person.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But can this be possible?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Why 'tis nothing sir, when a man gives his affections to it.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Good Pylades discourse a robbery or two, to satisfy these gentlemen of thy worth.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me my dear Orestes: causes have their quiddits, and 'tis ill jesting with bell-ropes.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? Pylades and Orestes?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Ay, he is my Pylades, and I am his Orestes: how like you the conceit?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, it's an old stale interlude devise: no, I'll give you names myself: look you, he shall be your Judas, and you shall be his elder tree to hang on.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay rather, let him be captain Pod, and this his motion; for he does nothing but show him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Excellent: or thus; you shall be holden, and he your camel.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: You do not mean to ride gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Faith let me end it for you gallants: you shall be his countenance, and he your resolution.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Troth that's pretty: how say you cavalier, shalt be so?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, most voices.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Faith I am easily yielding to any good impressions:

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Then give hands good resolution.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Mass he cannot say good countenance now (Properly) to him again.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Yes, by an irony.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O sir, the countenance of resolution should, as he's altogether grim and unpleasant.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good hours make music with your mirth gentlemen, and keep time to your humours: how now Carlo?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Monsieur Briske! many a long look have I extended for you sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good faith I must crave pardon; I was invited this morning ere I was out of my bed, by a bevy of ladies, to a banquet: whence it was almost one of Hercules' labours for me to come away, but that the respect of my promise did so prevail with me: I know they'll take it very ill, especially one that gave me this bracelet of her hair but over night, and this pearl another gave me from her forehead, marry she — what? are the writings ready?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I will send my man to know. Sirrah, go you to the notaries, and learn if he be ready: leave the dog sir.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: And how does my rare qualified friend Sogliardo? o signior Macilente! by these eyes I saw you not, I had saluted you sooner else on my troth: I hope sir I may presume upon you that you will not divulge my late cheek, or disgrace indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: You may sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: S'heart he knows some notorious jest by this gull, that he hath him so obsequious.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Monsieur Fastidius, do you see this fellow there? does he not look like a clown? would you think there's any thing in him?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Any thing in him? beshrew me, I; the fellow hath a good ingenious face.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: By this element, he is an ingenious tall man as ever swaggered about London: he and I call countenance and resolution, but his name is cavalier shift.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Cavalier, you knew signior clog, that was hanged for the robbery at harrow on the hill?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Knew him sir! why 'twas he gave all the directions for the action.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How? was't your project sir?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me countenance, you do me some wrong to make that public, which I imparted to you in private.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: God's will, here are none but friend's resolution.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: That's all one; things of consequence must have their respects, where, how, and to whom. Yes sir, he showed himself a true clog in the coherence of that affair sir; for if he had managed matters as they were corroborated to him, it had been better for him by a forty or fifty score of pounds sir, and he himself might ha' lived (In despite of fate) to have fed on woodcocks with the rest: but it was his heavy fortunes to sink poor clog, and therefore talk no more of him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Why, had he more agents then?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O God sir; ay, there were some present there, that were the nine worthies to him i'faith.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Ay sir, I can satisfy you at more convenient conference: but (For mine own part) I have now reconciled myself to other courses, and profess a living out of my other qualities.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay, he has left all now (I assure you) and is able to live like a gentleman by his quality. By this dog, he has the most rare gift in tobacco that ever you knew.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: S'heart, he keeps more ado with this monster, than ever banks did with his horse, or the fellow with the elephant.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: He will hang out his picture shortly in a cloth, you shall see.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O, he does manage a quarrel the best that ever you saw, for terms and circumstances.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Good faith signior (Now you speak of a quarrel) I'll acquaint you with a difference that happened between a gallant and myself: sir Puntarvolo, you know him if I should name him; signior Luculento.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Luculento! what inauspicious chance interposed itself betwixt your two loves?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
Faith sir, the same that sundered Agamemnon and great Thetis son; but let the cause escape sir: he sent me a challenge (Mixed with some few braves) which I restored, and in fine we met. Now indeed sir (I must tell you) he did offer at first very desperately, but without judgement: for look you sir. I cast
myself into this figure: now he, comes violently on, and withal advancing his rapier to strike, I thought to have taken his arm (For he had left his whole body to my election, and I was sure he could not recover his guard) sir, I missed my purpose in his arm, rashed his doublet sleeve, ran him close by the left cheek, and through his hair: he again lights me here, I had a gold cable hatband then new come up, (Which I wore about a murrey French hat I had) cuts my hatband (And yet it was massy, goldsmith's work) cuts my brims, which by good fortune (Being thick embroidered with gold twist, and spangles) disappointed the force of the blow: nevertheless it grazed on my shoulder, takes me away six purls of an Italian cutwork band I wore, cost me three pounds in the exchange but three days before.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: This was a strange encounter.

sp.speaker: Fastid.
sp.p: Nay you shall hear sir, with this we both fell out and breathed: now (Upon the second sign of his assault) I betook me to the former manner of my defence; he (On the other side) abandoned his body to the same danger as before, and follows me still with blows. But I (Being loath to take the deadly advantage that lay before me of his left side) made a kind of stramazon, ran him up to the hilts, through the doublet, through the shirt, and yet missed the skin. He (Making a reverse blow) falls upon my embossed girdle (I had thrown off the hangers a little before) strikes off a skirt of a thick laced satin doublet I had (Lined with some four taffetas) cuts of two panes embroidered with pearl, rends through the drawings out of tissue, enters the linings, and skips the flesh.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I wonder he speaks not of his wrought shirt.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
Here (In the opinion of mutual damage) we paused: but (Ere I proceed) I must tell you signior, that (In this last encounter) not having leisure to put off my silver spurs, one of the rowels catched hold of the ruffle of my boot, and (Being Spanish leather, and subject to tear) overthrows
me, rends me two pair of silk stockings (That I put on being somewhat a raw morning, a peach colour and another) and strikes me some half inch deepe into the side of the calf; he (Seeing the blood come) presently takes horse and away. I (Having bound up my wound with a piece of my wrought shirt)

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O comes it there?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Rid after him, and (Lighting at the court gate both together) embraced and marched hand in hand up into the presence.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well, by this we can guess what apparel the gentleman wore.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Before God it was a designment begun with much resolution, maintained with as much prowess, and ended with more humanity. How now, what says he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: The notary says he is ready sir, he stays but your worship's pleasure.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come we will go to him monsieur. Gentlemen shall we entreat you to be witnesses.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: You shall entreat me sir, come resolution.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I follow you good countenance.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Come signior, come, come.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.l: O, that there should be fortune
To clothe these men, so naked in desert,
And that the just storm of a wretched life,
Beats 'em not ragged for their wretched souls,
And since as fruitless, even as black as coals.

sp.speaker: Mitis.
sp.p:
Why but signior, how comes it that Fungoso appeared
not with his sister's intelligence to brisk.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Marry long of the evil angels that she gave him, who have indeed tempted the good simple youth to follow the tail of the fashion, and neglect the imposition of his friends. Behold here he comes, very worshipfully attended, and with good variety.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Fungoso with Taylor, Shoemaker, and haberdasher.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.l: Gramercy good shoemaker, I'll put too strings myself.
Now sir, let me see, what must you have for this hat?

sp.speaker: Haber.
sp.p: Here's the bill, sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: How dost become me, well?

sp.speaker: Tailor.
sp.p: Excellent sir, as ever you had any hat in your life.

sp.speaker: Haber.
sp.p: Nay faith sir, the hat's as good as any man i' this town can serve you. And will maintain fashion as long, never trust me for a groat else.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Does it apply well to my suit?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Exceeding well sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: How likest thou my suit haberdasher?

sp.speaker: Hab.
sp.p: By my troth sir 'tis very rarely well made, I never saw a suit sit better I can tell on.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Nay, we have no art to please our friends, we.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Here haberdasher tell this same.

sp.speaker: Haberdasher.
sp.p: Good faith sir, it makes you have an excellent body.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay (Believe me) I think I have as good a body in clothes as another.

sp.speaker: Tailor.
sp.p: You lack points to bring your apparel together.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I'll have points anon: how now? is't right?

sp.speaker: Hab.
sp.p: Faith sir 'tis too little, but upon farther hopes. Good morrow to you sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Farewell good haberdasher, well now master Smp let me see your bill.

sp.speaker: Mit. Cord.
sp.p: methinks he discharges his followers too thick, oh therein he saucily imitates some great man. I warrant you though he turns off them, he keeps this tailor in place of a page to follow him still.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: This bill is very reasonable in faith, hark you master Snip. Troth sir I am not altogether so well furnished at this present, as I could wish I were: but — if you'll do me the favour to take part in hand, you shall have all I have by Jesu.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Sir —

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: And but give me credit for the rest, till the beginning of the next term.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: O lord sir —

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Before God and by this light I'll pay you to the utmost, and acknowledge myself very deeply engaged to you by this hand.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Why how much have you there sir?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Marry I have here four angels, and fifteen shillings of white money, it's all I have as hope to be saved.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: You will not fail me at the next term with the rest.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: No and I do, pray God I be hanged. Let me never breathe again upon this mortal stage, as the philosopher calls it. By this air, and (As I am a gentleman) I'll hold.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: He were an iron-hearted fellow in my judgement, that would not credit him upon these monstrous others.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p:
Well sir, I'll not stick with any gentleman for a
trifle: you know what 'tis remains?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Ay sir, and I give you thanks in good faith, oh God how happy am I made in this good fortune. Well, now I'll go seek out monsieur Briske. God's so, I have forgotten ribbon for my shoes; and points. 'slid what luck's this? how shall I do? Master Snip, pray let me reduct some two or three shillings for points and ribbon, by Jesu I have utterly disfurnished myself in the default of memory, pray, le' me be beholding to you, it shall come home i'the bill believe me.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Faith sir, I can hardly depart with money, but I'll take up and send you by my boy presently. What coloured ribbon would you have?

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: What you shall think meet i'your judgement sir to my suit.

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: Well, I'll send you some presently.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: And points too sir?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.p: And points too sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Good lord how shall I study to deserve this kindness of you sir. Pray let your youth make haste, for I should have done a business an hour since, that I doubt I shall come too late. Now in good truth I am exceeding proud of my suit.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Do you observe the plunges that this poor gallant is put too (Signior) to purchase the fashion.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Ay, and to be still a fashion behind with the world, that's the sport.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Stay: oh here they come from sealed and delivered.

div.head: Scaena quinta.
div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Fastidius Briske, serving men with the dog.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Well now my whole venture is forth, I will resolve to depart shortly.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith sir Puntarvolo go to the court, and take leave of the ladies first.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I care not if it be this afternoons labour. Where is Carlo?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Here he comes.

div.stage: Enter Carlo, Sogliardo, shift, and Macilente.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Faith gallants, I am persuading this gentleman to turn courtier, he is a man of fair revenue, and his estate will bear the charge well, besides for his other gifts of the mind, or so, why, they are as nature lent him 'em, pure, simple, without any artificial drug or mixture of these two threadbare beggarly qualities, learning and knowledge, and therefore the more accommodate and genuine. Now for the life itself —

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: O, the most celestial, and full of wonder and delight that can be imagined signior, beyond all thought and apprehension of pleasure. A man lives there in that divine rapture, that he will think himself i' the third heaven for the time, and lose all sense of mortality whatsoever; when he shall behold such glorious (And almost immortal) beauties, hear such angelical and harmonious voices, discourse with such flowing and ambrosian spirits, whose wits as sudden as lightning, and humorous as nectar; o: it makes a man all quintessence and flame, and lifts him up (In a moment) to the very crystal crown o'the sky, where (Hovering in the strength of his imagination) he shall behold all the delights of the hesperides, the insulae fortunatae, Adonis' gardens, Tempe, or what else (Confined within the amplest verge of poesy) to be mere umbrae, and imperfect figures, conferred with the most essential felicity of your court.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Well this encomion was not extemporal, it came too perfectly off.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Besides sir, you shall never need to go to a hothouse, you shall sweat there with courting your mistress, or losing your money at primero, as well as in all the stoves in Flanders.
Marry this sir, you must ever be sure to carry a good strong perfume about you, that your mistress dog may smell you out amongst the rest; and (In making love to her) never fear to be out: for you may have a pipe of tobacco, or a base viol shall hang o'the wall of purpose, will put you in presently. The tricks your resolution has taught you in tobacco, (The whiff, and those sleights) will stand you in very good ornament there?

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: Ay, to some perhaps: but, and he should come to my mistress with tobacco (This gentleman knows) she'd reply upon him i'faith. O (By this bright sun) she has the most acute, ready, and facetious wit, that — tut there's no spirit able to stand her. You can report it signior, you have seen her?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Then can he report no less out of his judgement, I assure him.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Troth I like her well enough, but she's too self-conceited methinks .

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I indeed, she's a little too self-conceited, and 'twere not for that humour, she were the most to be admired lady in the world.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Indeed it is a humour that takes from her other excellencies.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why it may easily be made to forsake her in my thought.

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: Easily sir? then are all impossibilities easy.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: You conclude too quick upon me signior, what will you say if I make it so perspicuously appear now, that yourself shall confess nothing more possible.

sp.speaker: Fasti.
sp.p: Marry I will say, I will both applaud you, and admire you for it.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: And I will second him.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why I'll show you gentlemen, Carlo come hither.

div.stage: Macilente, Carlo, Puntarvolo, and briske, whisper.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Good faith I have a great humour to the court, what thinks my resolutions? shall I adventure?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Troth countenance, as you please; the place is a place of good reputation and capacity.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O, my tricks in tobacco (As Carlo says) will show excellent there.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Why you may go with these gentlemen now, and see fashions; and after, as you shall see correspondence.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: You say true. You will go with me resolution?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I will meet you countenance, about three or four of clock, but, to say to go with you I cannot, for (As I am apple John) I am to go before the cockatrice you saw this morning, and therefore pray, present me excused good countenance.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Farewell good resolution, but fail not to meet.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: As I live.

sp.speaker: P●nt
sp.p: Admirably excellent.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: If you can but persuade Sogliardo to the court, there's all now.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O let me alone, that's my task:

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Now by Jesu Macilente, it is above measure excellent: 'twill be the only courtly exploit that ever proved courtier ingenious.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Upon my soul it puts the lady quite out of her humour, and we shall laugh with judgement.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Come, the gentleman was of himself resolved to go with you, afore I moved it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why then gallants, you two and Carlo go afore to prepare the jest: Sogliardo and I will come some while after you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Pardon me, I am not for the court.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: That's true: Carlo comes not at the court indeed well, you shall leave it to the faculty of monsieur Briske, and myself; upon our lives we will manage it happily. Carlo shall bespeak supper at the mitre against we come back: where we will meet, and dimple our cheeks with laughter at the success.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, but will you all promise to come.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Myself shall manfrede it for them: he that fails, let his reputation lie under the lash of thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: God's so ', look who comes here.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: What, nephew?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Uncle, God save you; did you see a gentleman, one monsieur brisk? A courtier, he goes in such a suit as I do.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Here is the gentleman nephew, but not in such a suit.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Another suit!

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How now nephew?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Would you speak to me sir?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, when he has recovered himself: poor poll.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Some rosa-solis.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: How now signior?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: I am not well sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why this it is, to dog the fashion.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay come gentlemen, remember your affairs; his disease is nothing but the flux of apparel.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sirs, return to the lodging, keep the cat safe; I'll be the dog's guardian myself.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nephew, will you go to the court with us; these gentlemen and I are for the court: nay be not so melancholy.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: By god's lid I think no man in Christendom has that rascally fortune that I have.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Faith your suit is well enough signior.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Nay, not for that I protest; but I had an errand to monsieur Fastidius, and I have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why go along to the court with us, and remember it, come. Gentlemen, you three take one boat, and Sogliardo and I will take another: we shall be there instantly.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Content: good sir vouchsafe us your pleasance.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Farewell Carlo; remember.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I warrant you: would I had one of Kemp's shoes to throw after you.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Good fortune will close the eyes of our jest, fear not: and we shall frolic.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: This Macilente signior begins to be more sociable on a sudden methinks , than he was before, there is some portent in't, I believe.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: O he's a fellow of a strange nature. Now does he (In this calm of his humour) plot and store up a world of malicious thoughts in his brain, till he is so full with 'em, that you shall see the very torrent of his envy break forth, and against the course of all their affections oppose itself so violently, that you will almost have wonder to think how 'tis possible the current of their dispositions shall receive so quick and strong an alteration.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: I marry sir, this is that on which my expectation has dwelled all this while: for I must tell you signior (Though I was loath to interrupt the scene) yet I made it a question in mine own private discourse, how he should properly call it, every man out of his humour, when I saw all his actors so strongly pursue and continue their humours?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Why therein his art appears most full of lustre, and approacheth nearest the life, especially when in the flame and height of their humours they are laid flat, it fills the eye better, and with more contentment. How tedious a sight were it to behold a proud exalted tree lopped and cut down by degrees, when it might be felled in a moment? and to set the axe to it, before it came to that pride and fullness, were as not it have it grow.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Well I shall long till I see this fall you talk of.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: To help your longing, signior, let your imagination be swifter than a pair of oars, and by this, suppose Puntarvolo, Briske, Fungoso, and the dog, arrived at the court gate, and going up to the great chamber. Macilente and Sogliardo, we'll leave them on the water till possibility and natural means may land'em . Here come the gallants, now prepare your expectation.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Fastidius Briske, Fungoso, and the dog.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come lordings. Signior you are sufficiently instructed.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Who I sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: No, this gentleman. But stay, I take thought how to bestow my dog, he is no competent attendant for the presence.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Mass that is true in deed knight, you must not carry him into the presence.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I know it, and I (Like a dull beast) forgotten to bring one of my cormorants to attend me.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why you're best leave him at the porter's lodge.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Not so: his worth is too well known amongst them, to be forthcoming.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Slight, how'll you do then?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I must leave him with one that is ignorant of his quality, if I will have him to be safe. And see; here comes one that will carry coals, ergo, will hold my dog. My honest friend, may I commit the tuition of this dog to thy prudent care?

div.stage: Enter a groom with a basket.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: You may if you please sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Pray thee let me find thee here at my return: it shall not be long, till I will ease thee of thy employment, and please thee. Forth gentles.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Why, but will you leave him with so slight command, and infuse no more charge upon the fellow?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Charge? no, there wear no policy in that; that were to let him know the value of the gem he holds, and so, to tempt frail nature against her disposition. No, pray thee let thy honesty be sweet and short.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p:
But hark you gallants, and chiefly monsieur brisk, when we come in eye-shot or presence of this lady, let
not other matters carry us from our project: but (If we can) single her forth to some place.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: And be not too sudden, but let the device induce itself with good circumstance: on.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Is this the way? good truth here be fine hangings.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Honesty, sweet and short? marry it shall sir, doubt you not: for even at this instant if one would give me twenty pounds, I would not deliver him; there's for the sweet: but now, if any man come offer me but twopence, he shall have him; there's for the short now. 'sblood, what a mad humorous gentleman is this to leave his dog with me: I could run away with him now and he were worth any thing: well, I pray God send him quickly again.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Come on signior, now prepare to court this all-witted lady, most naturally and like yourself.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Faith and you say the word, I'll begin to her in tobacco.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: O, fie on't. no: you shall begin with, how does my sweet lady; or, why are you so melancholy madam? though she be very merry, it's all one: be sure to kiss your hand often enough; pray for her health, and tell her, how more than most fair she is: screw your face at' 'One side thus, and protest; let her fleer and look a skance, and hide her teeth with her fan, when she laughs a fit, to bring her into more matter; that's nothing: you must talk forward (Though it be without sense, so it be without blushing) 'tis most courtlike and well.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: But shall I not use tobacco at all?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O, by no means, 'twill but make your breath suspected; and that you use it only to confound the rankness of that.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay, I'll be advised sir by my friends.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: God's my life, see where sir Puntar's dog is.

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: I would the gentleman would return for his follower here, I'll leave him to his fortunes else.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: S'heart, 'twere the only true jest in the world to poison him now: ha? by God's will I'll do it, if I could but get him of the fellow. Signior Sogliardo, walk aside, and think upon some device to entertain the lady with.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: So I do sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: How now mine honest friend? whose dog-keeper art thou?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Dog-keeper sir? I hope I scorn that i'faith.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why? dost thou not keep a dog?

sp.speaker: Groom.
sp.p: Sir, now I do, and now I do not: I think this be sweet and short: make me his dog-keeper?

div.stage: Throws off the dog, and exit.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: This is excellent above expectation: nay stay sir, you'd be travailing; but I'll give you a dram shall shorten your voyage: here: so sir, I'll be bold to take my leave of you: now to the Turks court in the devil's name, for you shall never go on god's name. [kicks him out.]Sogliardo, come.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I ha' 't i'faith now, will sting it.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Take heed you lose it not signior, ere you come there: preserve it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: How like you this first exploit of his?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, a piece of true envy, but I expect the issue of the other device.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Here they come, will make it appear.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Saviolina, Fastidius Briske, Fungoso.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Why I thought sir Puntarvolo, you had been gone your voyage?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Dear, and most amiable lady, your divine beauties do bind me to those offices, that I cannot depart when I would.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p:
'Tis most courtlike spoken sir; but how might we do
to have a sight of your dog and cat?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: His dog's in the court, lady.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: And not your cat? how dare you trust her behind you sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Troth madam she hath sore eyes, and she doth keep her chamber: marry I have left her under sufficient guard: there are two of my hinds to attend her.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: I'll give you some water for her eyes: when do you go sir?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Certes sweet lady, I know not.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: He doth stay the rather madam, to present your acute judgement with so courtly, and well-parted a gentleman, as yet your ladyship hath never seen.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: What's he, gentle monsieur Briske? not that gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No lady, this is a kinsman of justice silence.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Pray sir, give me leave to report him: he's a gentleman (Lady) of that rare and admirable faculty, as (I protest) I know not his like in Europe: he is exceedingly valiant, an excellent scholar, and so exactly travailed, that he is able in discourse, to deliver you a model of any prince's court in the world: speaks the languages with that purity of phrase, and facility of accent, that it breeds astonishment: his wit, the most exuberant, and (Above wonder) pleasant, of all that ever entered the concave of this care.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis most true lady; marry he is no such excellent proper man.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: His travails have changed his complexion, madam.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: O sir Puntarvolo, you must think every man was not born to have my servant Briske's feature.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: But that which transcends all, lady; he doth so peerlessely imitate any manner of person for gesture, action, passion, or whatever —

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Ay, especially a rustic or a clown madam, that it is not possible for the sharpest-sighted wit (In the world) to discern any sparks of the gentleman in him, when he does it.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: O Monsieur Briske, be not so tyrannous to confine all wits within the compass of your own: not find the sparks of a gentleman in him, if he be a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: No in truth (Sweet lady) I believe you cannot.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Do you believe so? Why I can find sparks of a gentleman in you sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Ay, he is a gentleman madam, and a reveller.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Indeed I think I have seen your ladyship at our revels.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Like enough sir: but would I might see this wonder you talk of: may one have a sight of him for any reasonable sum?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Yes madam, he will arrive presently.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: What, and shall we see him clown it?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: i'faith (Sweet lady) that you shall: see here he comes.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: This is he; pray observe him lady.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Beshrew me, he clownes it properly indeed.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Nay, mark his courtship.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How does my sweet lady; hot and moist? Beautiful and lusty? ha?

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Beautiful and it please you sir, but not lusty.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O ho lady; it pleases you to say so in truth: and how does my sweet lady; in health? Bonaroba, quaeso? que novelles? que novelles? Sweet creature.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: O excellent: why gallants, is this he cannot be deciphered? they were very blear-witted i'faith that could not discern the gentleman in him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: But do you, in earnest lady?

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Do I sir? why if you had any true court-judgement in the carriage of his eye, and that inward power that forms his countenance, you might perceive his counterfeiting as clear as the noon day: alas; nay if you would have tried my wit indeed, you should never have told me he was a gentleman, but presented him for a true clown indeed; and then have seen if I could have deciphered him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Before God, her ladyship says true (Knight:) but does he not affect the clown most naturally, mistress?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: O, she cannot but affirm that, out of the bounty of her judgement.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Nay out of doubt he does well, for a gentleman to imitate; but I warrant you, he becomes his natural carriage of the gentleman, much better than his clownery.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Tis strange in truth, her ladyship should see so far into him.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Ay, is't not.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Faith as easily as may be: not decipher him, quoth you?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Good sadness, I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why, has she deciphered him, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Oh most miraculously, and beyond admiration.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: She hath given most infallible signs of the gentleman in him, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Why gallants, let me laugh at you a little: was this your device, to try my judgement in a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay lady, do not scorn us, though you have this gift of perspicacy above others: what if he should be no gentleman now, but a clown indeed lady?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: How think you of that? would not your ladyship be out of your humour?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O, but she knows it is not so.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: What if he were not a man, ye may as well say? nay if your worships could gull me so indeed, you were wiser than you are taken for.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: In good faith lady, he is a very perfect clown, both by father and mother: that I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: O sir, you are very pleasurable.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay, do but look on his hand, and that shall resolve you: look you lady, what a palm here is.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Tut, that was with holding the plough.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p:
The plough! did you discern any such thing in him
madam?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Faith no, she saw the gentleman as bright as at noonday she: she deciphered him at first.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Troth I am sorry your ladyship's sight should be so suddenly struck.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: O, you're goodly beagles!

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: What, is she gone?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Nay stay sweet lady; que novelles, que novelles.

sp.speaker: Savi.
sp.p: Out, you fool you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: She's out of her humour i'faith.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Nay, let's follow it while 'tis hot gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Come, on mine honour we'll make her blush in the presence: my spleen is great with laughter.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Your laughter will be a child of a feeble life I believe sir. Come signior, your looks are too dejected methinks : why mix you not mirth with the rest?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: By God's will this suit frets me at the soul. I'll have it altered tomorrow sure.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I am come to the court to meet with my countenance Sogliardo: poor men must be glad of such countenance, when they can get no better. Well, need may insult upon a man, but it shall never make him despair of consequence: the world will say, 'tis base; tush, base! 'tis base to live under the earth, not base to live above it, by any means.

div.stage: Enter Puntarvolo, Fastidius, Sogliardo, Fungoso, Macilente.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: The poor lady is most miserably out of her humour i'faith.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: There was never so witty a jest broken at the tilt, of all the court wits christened.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: O, this applause taints it foully.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I think I did my part in courting. O resolution!

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Ay me, my dog.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: God's precious, go seek for the fellow, good signior.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Here, here I left him.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why none was here when we came in now, but cavalier shift, inquire of him.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Did you see sir Puntarvolo's dog here cavalier, since you came?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: His dog sir? he may look his dog sir; I see none of his dog sir.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Upon my life he hath stol'n your dog sir, and been hired to it by some that have ventured with you; you may guess by his peremptory answers.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Not unlike; for he hath been a notorious thief by his own confession. Sirrah, where's my dog?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Charge me with your dog sir? I ha' none of your dog sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Villain, thou liest.

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Lie sir? 'sblood you're but a man sir.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Rogue and thief, restore him.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Take heed sir Puntarvolo what you do; he'll bear no coals I can tell you (Of my word.)

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: This is rare.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: It's mar'le he stabs you not: by this light, he hath stabbed forty for forty times less matter, I can tell you, of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I will make thee stoop, thou abject.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Make him stoop sir! Gentlemen pacify him or he'll be killed.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Is he so tall a man?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Tall a man? if you love his life stand betwixt 'em ▪ make him stoop!

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: My dog villain, or I will hang thee: thou hast confessed robberies, and other felonious acts to this gentleman thy countenance.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: I'll bear no witness.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: And without my dog I will hang thee, for them.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: What? kneel to thine enemy?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: Pardon me good sir; God is my judge I never did robbery in all my life.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: O sir Puntarvolo, your dog lies giving up the ghost in the woodyard.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: 'Sblood is he not dead yet?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: O, my dog born to disastrous fortune! pray you conduct me sir.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: How? did you never do any robbery in your life?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: O this is good: so he swore sir.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Ay, I heard him. And did you swear true sir?

sp.speaker: Shift.
sp.p: I (As God shall have part of my soul sir) I never robbed any man I; never stood by the high way side sir, but only said so, because I would get myself a name and be counted a tall man.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Now out base Viliaco: thou my resolution? I thy countenance? By this light gentlemen, he hath confessed to me the most inexorable company of robberies, and damned himself that he did 'em; you never heard the like: out scoundrel out, follow me no more I command thee: out of my sight, go, hence, speak not: I will not hear thee; away Camouccio.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O, how I do feed upon this now, and fat myself? here were a couple unexpectedly dishumoured: well, by this time I hope sir Puntarvolo and his dog are both out of humour to travail: nay gentlemen, why do you not seek out the knight, and comfort him? our supper at the mitre must of necessity hold tonight , if you love your reputations.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Before God I am so melancholy for his dog's disaster, but I'll go.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Faith and I may go too, but I know I shall be so melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Tush, melancholy? you must forget that now, and remember you lie at the mercy of a fury: Carlo will rack your sinews asunder, and rail you to dust if you come not.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O then their fear of Carlo be like, makes them hold their meeting.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ay, here he comes: conceive him but to be entered the mitre, and 'tis enough.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Holla: where be these shot-sharks?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: By and by: you're welcome good master Buffone.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Where's George? call me George hither quickly.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: What wine please you have sir? I'll draw you that's neat master Buffone.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Away neophyte, do as I bid; bring my dear George to me: mass here he comes.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Welcome master Carlo.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What's supper ready, George?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Ay sir, almost: will you have the cloth laid, master Carlo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, what else: are none of the gallants come yet?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: None yet sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Stay, take me with you George: let me have a good fat loin of pork laid to the fire presently.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: It shall sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And withal, hear you? draw me the biggest shaft you have out of thee but you wot of: away, you know my meaning George, quick.

sp.speaker: George.
sp.p: Done sir.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Sblood, I never hungered so much for thing in my life, as I do to know our gallants success at the court: now is that lean bald-rib Macilente, that salt villain, plotting some mischievous device, and lies a soaking in their frothy humours like a dry crust, till he has drunk 'em all up: could the kecks but hold up's eyes at other men's happiness in any reasonable proportion, 'slid the slave were to be loved next heaven, above honour, wealth, rich fare, apparel, wenches, all the delights of the belly, and the groin, whatever.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Here master Carlo.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Is't right, boy?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Ay sir, I assure you 'tis right.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Well said my dear George, depart: come, my small gimlet, you in the false scabbard, away; so: now to you sir burgomaster, let's taste of your bounty.

div.stage: Puts forth the drawer and shuts the door.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: What, will he deal upon such quantities of wine alone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: You shall perceive that sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I marry sir, here's purity ▪ oh George, I could bite off thy nose for this now: sweet rogue, he has drawn nectar, the very soul of the grape: I'll wash my temples with some on't presently, and drink some half a score draughts; 'twill heat the brain, kindle my imagination, I shall talk nothing but crackers and firework tonight . So sir; please you to be here sir, and I here: so.

div.stage: He sets the two cups asunder, and first drinks with the one, and pledges with the other.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: This is worth the observation, signior.

sp.speaker: Carl. 1 cup
sp.p: Now sir, here's to you; and I present you with so much of my love.

sp.speaker: 2 Cup.
sp.p: I take it kindly from you sir. (Drinks)and will return you the like proportion: but withal sir, remembering the merry night we had at the countesses; you know where sir.

sp.speaker: 1 cup.
sp.p: By Jesu you do put me in mind now of a very necessary office, which I will propose in your pledge sir: the health of that honourable countess, and the sweet lady that sat by her sir.

2 I do vail to it with reverence. (Drinks.)2. And now signior, with these ladies, I'll be bold to mix the health of your divine mistress. 1. Do you know her sir? 2 oh lord sir, ay, and in the respectful memory and mention of her, I could wish this wine were the most 〈◊〉 is drug in the world.
1 good faith sir, you do honour me 〈◊〉 exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Whom should he personate in this, signior?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Faith I know not sir, observe, observe him.

2 if it were the basest filth or mud that runs in the channel, I am bound to pledge it by God sir. (Drinks.)and now sir, here is again a replenished bowl sir, which I will reciprocally return upon you to the health of the count Frugal. 1 the count Frugale's health sir? I'll pledge it on my knees by Jesu. 2 will you sir? I'll drink it on my knees then, by the lord.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: Why this is strange.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Have you heard a better drunken dialogue?

2 nay, do me right sir. 1 so I do in good faith. 2 good faith you do not; mine was fuller. 1 why by Jesu it was not. 2 by Jesu it was, and you do lie. 1 lie sir. 2 I sir. 1 'swounds you rascal. 2 oh, come, stab if you have a mind to it. 1 stab? dost thou think I dare not? [in his own person.] Nay, I beseech you gentlemen, what means this; nay look, for shame respect your reputations.

div.stage: Ouer-turnes wine, pot, cups, and all.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why how now Carlo; what humour's this?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O my good mischief, art thou come? where are the rest? where are the rest?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith three of our ordinance are burst.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Burst? how comes that?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith overcharged, overcharged.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But did not the train hold?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: O yes, and the poor lady is irrecoverably blown up.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why, but which of the munition is miscarried? ha?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Imprimis, sir Puntarvolo: next, the countenance, and resolution.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: How? how for these love of God?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Troth the resolution is proved recreant; the countenance hath changed his copy; and the passionate knight, is shedding funeral tears over his departed dog.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What's his dog dead?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Poisoned 'tis thought: marry how, or by whom, that's left for some cunning woman here of the Bankside to resolve: for my part, I know nothing, more than that we are like to have an exceeding melancholy supper of it.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Slife, and I had purposed to be extraordinarily merry: I had drunk off a good preparative of old sack here: but will they come, will they come?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: They will assuredly come: marry Carlo (As thoulovest me) run over 'em all freely tonight , and especially the knight; spare no sulphurous jest that may come out of that sweaty forge of thine, but ply 'em with all manner of shot, minion, saker, culverin, or any thing what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I warrant thee my dear case of petronels, so I stand not in dread of thee, but that thou'lt second me.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why my good German tapster, I will.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What George. Lomtero, Lomtero, etc.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Did you call, master Carlo?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: More nectar, George: Lomtero, etc.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Your meat's ready sir and your company were come.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Is the loin a pork enough?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: I sir, it is enough?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Pork? S'heart what dost thou with such a greasy dish; I think thou dost varnish thy face with the fat on't, it looks so like a gluepot.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
True, my raw-boned rogue: and if thou wouldst farce thy lean ribs with it too, they would not (Like ragged lathes) rub out so many doublets as they do: but thou knowest not a good dish, thou. O, it's the only nourishing meat in the world: no marvel though that saucy stubborn generation the Jews, were forbidden it: for what would they ha' done, well pampered with fat pork, that durst murmur
at their maker out of garlic and onions. 'sblood fed with it, the 〈◊〉 strummell patched, goggle-eyed Grumble doryes, would ha' gigantomachized. Well said my sweet George, fill, fill.

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: This savours too much of profanation.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: O servetur ad imum, qualis ab incepto processerit, et sibo constet. The necessity of his vain compels a toleration: for, bar this, and dash him out of humour before his time.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Tis an axiom in natural philosophy, what comes nearest the nature of that it feeds, converts quicker to nourishment, and doth sooner essentiate. Now nothing in flesh and entrails, assimulates or resembles man more, than a hog or swine.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: True; and he (To requite their courtesy) oftentimes doffeth off his own nature, and puts on theirs; as when he becomes as churlish as a hog, or as drunk as a sow: but to your conclusion.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Marry I say, nothing resembling man more than a swine, it follows, nothing can be more nourishing: for indeed (But that it abhors from our nice nature) if we fed one upon another, we should shoot up a great deal faster, and thrive much better: I refer me to your long-lane cannibals, or such like: but since 'tis so contrary; pork, pork; is your only feed.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: I take it your devil be of the same diet; he would never ha' desired to been incorporated into swine else. O here comes the melancholy mess: upon 'em Carlo, charge, charge.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Before God sir Puntarvolo, I am sorry for your heaviness; body a me, a shrewd mischance: why had you no unicorn horn, nor bezoar's stone about you? ha?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sir, I would request you be silent.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay, to him again.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Take comfort good knight, if your cat ha' recovered
her cataract, fear nothing; your dog's mischance may be holpen.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Say how (Sweet Carlo) for so God mend me, the poor knights moans draw me into fellowship of his misfortunes. But be not discouraged good sir Puntarvolo, I am content your adventure shall be performed upon your cat.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: I believe you musk-cod, I believe you, for rather than thou wouldst make present repayment, thou wouldst take it upon his own bare return from Callice.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay god's life, he'd be content (So he were well rid out of his company) to pay him five for one at his next meeting him in Paul's. But for your dog, sir Puntar, if he be not outright dead, there is a friend of mine a quacksalver, shall put life in him again, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: O no, that comes too late.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: God's precious knight, will you suffer this?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Drawer; get me a candle and hard wax presently.

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Ay, and bring up supper; for I am so melancholy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ah signior, where's your resolution?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: Resolution! hang him rascal: oh Carlo, if you love me do not mention him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why, how so? how so?

sp.speaker: Sog.
sp.p: O the arrantest crocodile that ever christian was acquainted with. By Jesu, I shall think the worse of tobacco while I live for his sake: I did think him to be as tall a man —

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay Buffone, the knight, the knight.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Sblood, he looks like an image carved out of box, full of knots: his face is (For all the world) like a Dutch purse with the mouth downward; his beard's the tassells: and he walks (Let me see) as melancholy as one o'the master's side in the counter. Do you hear sir Puntar?

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sir, I do entreat you no more, but enjoin you to silence, as you affect your peace.

sp.speaker: C●●..
sp.p:
Nay but dear knight understand (Here are none but friends, and such as wish you well) I would ha' you do this now; flame your dog presently (But in any case keep the head) and
stuff his skin well with straw, as you see these dead monsters at Bartholmew fair.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: I shall be sudden I tell you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Or if you like not that sir, get me somewhat a less dog and clap into the skin; here is a slave about the town here, a Jew, one Yohan; or a fellow that makes periwigs will glue it on artificially, it shall never be discerned; besides, 'twill be so much the warmer for the hound to travel in you know.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Sir Puntarvolo, 'sdeath can you be so patient?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Or thus sir: you may have (As you come through Germany) a familiar for little or nothing shall turn itself into the shape of your dog, or any thing (What you will) for certain hours: gods my life knight, what do you mean? you'll offer no violence, will you? Hold, hold.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: 'Sblood you slave, you bandog you.

sp.speaker: Carlo.
sp.p: As you love God, stay the enraged knight, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: By my knighthood, he that stirs in his rescue, dies. Drawer be gone.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Ay, are you howling, you wolf? Gentlemen, as you tender your lives, suffer no man to enter, till my revenge be perfect. Sirrah Buffone, lie down; make no exclamations, but down; down you cur, or I will make thy blood flow on my rapier hilts:

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Sweet knight hold in thy fury, and 'fore God I'll honour thee more than the Turk does Mahomet.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Down (I say.) Who's there?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Here's the constable, open the doors.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Good Macilente.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Open no door, if the Adalantado of Spain were here, he should not enter: on, help me with the light, gentlemen: you knock in vain sir officer.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Et tu Brute.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: Sirrah close your lips, or I will drop it in thine eyes by heaven.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: O, o.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Open the door, or I will break it open.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay good constable have patience a little, you shall come in presently, we have almost done.

sp.speaker: Punt.
sp.p: So; now, are you out of your humour sir. Shift gentlemen.

div.stage: Enter constable with officers, and stay briske.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Lay hold upon this gallant, and pursue the rest.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Lay hold on me sir! for what?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Marry for your riot here sir, with the rest of your companions.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: My riot! God's my judge, take heed what you do; Carlo did I offer any violence?

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: O sir, you see he is not in case to answer you, and that makes you so peremptory.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Peremptory, shife I appeal to the drawers, if I did him any hard measure.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: They are all gone, there's none of them will be laid any hold on.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Well sir, you are like to answer till the rest can be found out.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: 'Sblood I appeal to George here.

sp.speaker: Constable
sp.p: Tut George was not here: away with him to the counter sirs. Come sir you were best get yourself dressed somewhere.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Good lord that master Carlo could not take heed, and knowing what a gentleman the knight is if he be angry.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: A pox on 'em, they have left all the meat on our hands, would they were choked with it for me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What are they gone sirs.

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: O here's master Macilente.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Sirrah George d'ye see that concealment there? that napkin under the table?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: God's so ', signior Fungoso!

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: He's a good pawn for the reckoning; be sure you keep him here, and let him not go away till I come again, though he offer to discharge all; I'll return presently.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Sirrah, we have a pawn for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: What? of Macilente?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: No; look under the table.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I hope all be quiet now; if I can get but forth of this street, I care not. Masters, I pray you tell me, is the constable gone?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: What? Master Fungoso?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: Was't not a good device the same of me sirs?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Yes faith; ha' you been here all this while?

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: O God I: good sirs look and the coast be clear, I'd fain be going.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: All's clear sir, but the reckoning; and that you must clear and pay before you go, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I pay? 'slight, I eat not a bit since I came into the house yet.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Why you may when you please sir, 'tis all ready below that was bespoken.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Bespoken? not by me, I hope?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: By you sir? I know not that: but 'twas for you and your company, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Fun.
sp.p: My company? 'slid I was an invited guest, so I was.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Faith we have nothing to do with that sir, they're all gone but you, and we must be answered; that's the short and the long on't.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay, if you will grow to extremities, my masters, then would this pot, cup, and all were in my belly, if I have a cross about me.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: What, and have such apparel? Do not say so, signior, that mightily discredits your clothes.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: By Jesu the tailor had all my money this morning, and yet I must be fain to alter my suit too: good sirs, let me go, 'tis Friday night; and in good truth I have no stomach in the world to eat any thing.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: That's no matter so you pay sir.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Pay? God's light, with what conscience can you ask me to pay that I never drank for?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Yes sir, I did see you drink once.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: By this cup (Which is silver) but you did not, you do me infinite wrong, I looked in the pot once indeed, but I did not drink.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Well sir, if you can satisfy my master, it shall be all one to us. By and by.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Lose not yourself now signior.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Tut sir, you did bear too hard a conceit of me in that, but I will now make my love to you most transparent, in spite of any dust of suspicion, that may be raised to dim it: and henceforth since I see it is so against your humour, I will never labour to persuade you.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Why I thank you signior, but what's that you tell me may concern my peace so much?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith sir 'tis thus. Your wife's brother signior Fungoso, being at supper tonight at a tavern with a sort of gallants: there happened some division amongst 'em, and he is left in pawn for the reckoning: now if ever you look that time shall present you with a happy occasion to do your wife some gracious and acceptable service, take hold of this opportunity, and presently go and redeem him; for being her brother, and his credit so amply engaged as now it is, when she shall hear (As he cannot himself, but he must out of extremity report it) that you came and offered yourself so kindly, and with that respect of his reputation, 'slud the benefit cannot but make her dote, and grow mad of your affections.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p:
Now by heaven Macilente, I acknowledge myself exceedingly indebted to you, by this kind tender of your love; and I am sorry to remember that I was ever so rude to neglect
a friend of your worth, bring me shoes and a cloak there, I was going to bed if you had not come, what tavern is it?

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: The mitre sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Oh; why Fido, my shoes. Good faith it cannot but please her exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Come, I mar'le what piece of nightwork you have in hand now, that you call for your cloak and your shoes: what, is this your pander?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: O sweet wife speak lower, I would not he should hear thee for a world —

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Hang him rascal, I cannot abide him for his treachery, with his wild quickset beard there. Whether go you now with him?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: No whether with him dear wife, I go alone to a place, from whence I will return instantly. Good Macilente acquaint not her with it by any means, it may come so much the more accepted, frame some other answer, I'll come back immediately.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Nay, and I be not worthy to know whether you go, stay till I take knowledge of your coming back.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Hear you mistress Deliro.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: So sir, and what say you?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Faith lady, my intents will not deserve this slight respect, when you shall know 'em.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Your intents? why, what may your intents be for god's sake?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Troth the time allows no circumstance lady, therefore know, this was but a device to remove your husband hence, and bestow him securely, whilst (With more conveniency) I might report to you a misfortune that hath happened to monsieur Briske; nay comfort sweet lady. This night (Being at supper) a sort of young gallants committed a riot, for the which he (Only) is apprehended and carried to the counter, where if your husband and other creditors should but have knowledge of him, the poor gentleman were undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Ay me, that he were.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Now therefore, if you can think upon any present means for his delivery, do not foreslow it. A bribe to the officer that committed him, will do it.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O God sir, he shall not want for a bribe: pray you, will you commend me to him, and say I'll visit him presently.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: No lady, I shall do you better service in protracting your husband's return, that you may go with more safety?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Good truth so you may; farewell good sir ▪ lord how a woman may be mistaken in a man? I would have sworn upon all the testaments in the world he had not loved master Briske. Bring me my keys there maid: alas good gentleman, if all I have i' this earthly world will pleasure him, it shall be at his service.

sp.speaker: Mitis.
sp.p: How Macilente sweats i' this business, if you mark him?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: Ay, you shall see the true picture of spite anon, here comes the pawn and his redeemer.

div.stage: Enter Deliro, Fungoso, drawer following them.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Come brother, be not discouraged for this man, what?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: No truly, I am not discouraged, but I protest to you brother I have done imitating any more gallants either in purse or apparel, but as shall become a gentleman for good carriage or so.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: You say well. This is all i' the bill here? is't not?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: I sir.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: There's your money, tell it: and brother, I am glad I met with so good occasion to show my love to you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I will study to deserve it in good truth, and I live.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: What is't right?

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I sir, and I thank you.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Let me have a capon's leg saved, now the reckoning is paid.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: You shall sir:

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Where's signior Deliro?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Here Macilente.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Hark you sir, ha' you dispatched this same?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I marry have I.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Well then, I can tell you news, Briske is i' the counter.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I' the counter?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: 'Tis true sir, committed for the stir here tonight . Now would I have you send your brother home afore, with the report of this your kindness done him to his sister, which will so pleasingly possess her, and out of his mouth too, that i' the mean time you may clap your action on Briske, and your wife (Being in so happy a mood) cannot entertain it ill by any means.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, she cannot indeed, I think.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Think? why 'tis past thought, you shall never meet the like opportunity, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I will do it. Brother pray you go home afore, this gent. and I have some private business; and tell my sweet wife, I'll come presently.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: I will brother.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: And signior, acquaint your sister, how liberally and out of his bounty, you brother has used you. (Do you see?) made you a man of good reckoning; redeemed that you never were possessed of, credit; gave you as gentlemanlike terms as might be; found no fault with your coming behind the fashion; nor nothing.

sp.speaker: Fung.
sp.p: Nay I am out of those humours now.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Well, if you be out, keep your distance, and be not made a shot-clog no more. Come signior, let's make haste.

sp.speaker: Fallace.
sp.p: O master Fastidius, what pity is't to see so sweet a man as you are, in so sour a place?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.p: As upon her lips does she mean?

sp.speaker: Mit.
sp.p: O, this is to be imagined the counter belike?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Troth fair lady, 'tis first the pleasure of the fates, and next of the constable to have it so, but, I am patient, and indeed comforted the more in your kind visitation.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Nay, you shall be comforted in me more than this, if you please sir. I sent you word by my brother sir, that my husband laid to rest you this morning, I know not whether you received it, or no?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No believe it, sweet creature, your brother gave me no such intelligence.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O the lord!

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: But has your husband any such purpose?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O God master brisk, yes: and therefore be presently discharged; for if he come with his actions upon you (Lord deliver you) you are in for one half a score year; he kept a poor man in Ludgate once, twelve year for sixteen shillings. Where's your keeper, for god's love call him, let him take a bribe, and dispatch you, lord how my heart trembles! here are no spies? are there?

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: No sweet mistress, why are you in this passion?

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O Christ master Fastidius, if you knew how I took up my husband today, when he said he would arrest you; and how I railed at him that persuaded him to't, the scholar there, (Who on my conscience loves you now) and what care I took to send you intelligence by my brother; and how I gave him four sovereigns for his pains; and now, how I came running out hither without man or boy with me, so soon as I heard on't; you'd say, I were in a passion indeed: your keeper for God's sake. O master Briske (As 'tis in Euphues) hard is the choice, when one is compelled either by silence to die with grief, or by speaking to live with shame.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p:
Fair lady I conceive you, and may this kiss assure
you, that where adversity hath (As it were) contracted, prosperity shall not — god's light your husband.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: I? is't thus!

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why how now signior Deliro? has the wolf seen you? ha? hath Gorgon's head made marble on you?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.l: Some planet strike me dead.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Why look you sir, I told you, you might have suspected this long afore, had you pleased; and ha' saved this labour of admiration now, and passion, and such extremities as this frail lump of flesh is subject unto. Nay, why do you not dote now signior? Methinks you should say it were some enchantment, deceptio visus, or so, ha? if you could persuade yourself it were a dream now, 'twere excellent: faith try what you can do signior; it may be your imagination will be brought to it in time, there's nothing impossible.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p: Sweet husband?

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Out lascivious strumpet.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: What? did you see how ill that stale vain became him afore, of sweet wife, and dear heart? and are you fallen just into the same now? with sweet husband. Away, follow him, go, keep state, what? Remember you are a woman: turn impudent: give him not the head, though you givehim the horns, away. Exit Fallace.and yet methinks you should take your leave of infans-perdus here, your forlorn hope. How now monsieur brisk: what? Friday at night? and in affliction too? and yet your Pulpamenta? your delicate morsels: I perceive the affection of ladies and gentlewomen, pursues you wheresoever you go monsieur.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: Now in good faith (And as I am gentle) there could not have come a thing i' this world to have distracted me more than the wrinkled fortunes of this poor dame.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: O yes sir: I can tell you a thing will distract you much better, believe it. Signior Deliro has entered three actions against you, three actions monsieur: marry one of them (I'll put you in comfort) is but three thousand mark, and the other two some five thousand pound together, trifles, trifles.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O God, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: Nay not altogether so sir, the knight must have his hundred pound repaid, that'll help too, and then sixscore pound for a diamond: you know where? these be things will weigh monsieur; they will weigh.

sp.speaker: Fast.
sp.p: O Jesu!

sp.speaker: Maci.
sp.p: What do you sigh? this it is to kiss the hand of a countess, to have her coach sent for you, to hang poniards in ladies' garters, to wear bracelets of their hair, and for every one of these great favours to give some slight jewel of five hundred crowns, or so, why 'tis nothing. Now monsieur, you see the plague that treads o'the heels of your foppery, well, go your ways in; remove yourself to the twopenny ward quickly to save charges, and there set up your rest to spend sir Puntar's hundred pound for him. Away good pomander, go.

div.l: Why here's a change: now is my soul at peace,
I am as empty of all envy now,
As they of merit to be envied at,
My humour (Like a flame) no longer lasts
Than it hath stuff to feed it, and their virtue,
Being now raked up in embers of their folly,
Affords no ampler subject to my spirit;
I am so far from malicing their states,
That I begin to pity 'em: it grieves me
To think they have a being; I could wish
They might turn wise upon it, and be saved now,
So heaven were pleased: but let them vanish vapours.
And now with asper's tongue (Though not his shape)
Kind patrons of our sports (You that can judge,
And with discerning thoughts measure the pace
of our strange muse in this her maze of humour,
You, whose true notions do confine the former
And nature of sweet poesy) to you
I tender solemn and most duteous thanks,
For your stretched patience and attentive grace.
We know (And we are pleased to know so much)
The cates that you have tasted were not seasoned
For every vulgar palate, but prepared
To banquet pure and apprehensive ears:
Let then their voices speak for our desert;
Be their applause the trumpet to proclaim
Defiance to rebelling ignorance,
And the green spirits of some tainted few,
That (Spite of pity) betray themselves
To scorn and laughter; and like guilty children,
Publish their infancy before their time,
By their own fond exception: such as these
We pawn 'em to your censure, till time, wit,
Or observation, set some stronger seal
Of judgement on their judgements; and entreat
The happier spirits in this fair-filled globe,
(So many as have sweet minds in their breasts,
And are too wife to think themselves are taxed
In any general figure, or too virtuous
To need that wisdom's imputation:)
